Given the question statement:I don't know what else to say about this horrible movie that hasn't already been said. Honestly I have only myself to be angry with. I should have know better when I saw the title of this movie that it would be a horrible piece of crap, but I loved War Games so I indulged my whim. I will live to regret that decision the rest of my life. From the very start when the government people explained that their super computer could determine who a terrorist was just by how well they played a video game I knew I was in for a ride though the land-that-good-writing-forgot. The list of very, very, very bad plot lines, dialog, and acting is so long I would crash IMDb if I tried to post it. To those people who said that they have seen worst movies than this one please tell me. I am actually curious to see something that could top this steaming pile of horse dung.If you think this sentence is positive, the answer is 1, and the negative answer is 0 Use following thought to solve it:###Thinking Let's tackle this movie review. At first glance, the title "I don't know what else to say about this horrible movie that hasn't already been said" sets a pretty negative tone. The user mentions they "have only myself to be angry with" for watching it, which is more self-reproach than anything else, but it reinforces the negative sentiment. Wait, they admit they should have known better when they saw the title, suggesting the title itself was a red flag. But they "loved War Games" and decided to indulge their whim, which is a nice touch—shows they're not entirely closed off to the idea. However, the next sentence is a bit extreme: "I will live to regret that decision the rest of my life." Okay, that's pretty negative. From there, the review gets even worse. The premise is mocked: "when the government people explained that their super computer could determine who a terrorist was just by how well they played a video game I knew I was in for a ride though the land-that-good-writing-forgot." The use of "land-that-good-writing-forgot" is a clever way to say the writing was atrocious. The list of "very, very, very bad plot lines, dialog, and acting is so long I would crash IMDb if I tried to post it." That's a strong statement, emphasizing just how bad everything was. The user even challenges others: "To those people who said that they have seen worst movies than this one please tell me. I am actually curious to see something that could top this steaming pile of horse dung." Ouch, that's harsh. They're essentially saying they can't imagine anything worse, which is a pretty negative sentiment. However, there's a moment where I almost thought there might be a twist. The user mentions they loved War Games and indulged their whim, which could be seen as a positive thing. But then they immediately follow it with regretting the decision for the rest of their life. So, any potential positivity is swiftly squashed. They also mention that the title should have warned them, but they hoped for something like War Games. That initial hope quickly fades when the movie starts. The opening scene alone confirmed their worst fears. The list of bad plot lines, dialog, and acting is so extensive that they couldn't even list them all without crashing IMDb. That's a hyperbole, but it drives home how bad the movie was. They're so curious to find something worse that they openly ask for recommendations, which suggests they can't believe anything could be worse than this. It's like they're daring someone to top it, but they don't really think anything can. The user is clearly disappointed and frustrated, and their language reflects that. I did briefly wonder if there might be some sarcasm or hidden positivity, but everything points to a scathing review. They even use the phrase "steaming pile of horse dung," which leaves no doubt about their opinion. The mention of War Games is more a setup for how much worse this movie was, not a testament to its quality. So, after all that, is this sentence positive or negative? The overwhelming sentiment is negative. The user expresses regret, disappointment, and frustration with the movie. They mock the premise, the writing, the plot lines, the dialog, and the acting. The only positive mention is their love for War Games, but that's used to contrast how bad this movie is. Given the question statement:Sloppily directed, witless comedy that supposedly spoofs the "classic" 50s "alien invasion" films, but really is no better than them, except of course in the purely technical department (good makeup effects). And any spoof that is worse than its target is doomed to fail ("Casino Royale", "Our Man Flint" are worse than almost any James Bond movie). After two hours of hearing the screeching voices of the aliens, you'll be begging for some peace and quiet. (*1/2)If you think this sentence is positive, the answer is 1, and the negative answer is 0 Use following thought to solve it:###Thinking Let's tackle this review to determine whether it's positive or negative. The review is for a comedy that spoofs classic 50s alien invasion films. Right off the bat, the description "sloppily directed, witless comedy" sets a negative tone. The use of "sloppily" and "witless" are clear criticisms of the film's direction and humor. The review mentions that the film "supposedly spoofs the 'classic' 50s 'alien invasion' films," implying that it doesn't succeed in its goal. It goes on to say, "but really is no better than them, except of course in the purely technical department (good makeup effects)." So, while the makeup effects get a nod, the overall quality is deemed no better than the films it's spoofing. Wait, perhaps the film isn't entirely bad? However, the next part pours cold water on any lingering hope. The review compares the film to other spoofs that are worse than their targets, like "Casino Royale" and "Our Man Flint" being worse than James Bond movies. By drawing this comparison, the reviewer is suggesting that this comedy is also worse than the films it's spoofing. This seems to confirm that the film fails in its comedic mission. Then we have the screeching alien voices. The reviewer states, "After two hours of hearing the screeching voices of the aliens, you'll be begging for some peace and quiet." This is a clear negative, emphasizing how irritating the sound design is. Let's not forget the rating: "(*1/2)". That's a rating of 1.5 stars out of 5, which is pretty dismal. Even though there's a mention of good makeup effects, the overall tone is overwhelmingly negative. The reviewer seems to be saying that while the technical aspects might be decent, the film is witless, sloppily directed, and worse than the films it's spoofing. Initially, I thought the mention of good makeup effects might be a saving grace, but then I remembered that any positive aspect is overshadowed by the negative. The reviewer's comparison to other spoofs that are worse than their targets drives home the point that this film doesn't succeed in its genre. The screeching alien voices are just the cherry on top of the negative sundae. Wait, maybe the reviewer is being sarcastic when they mention the good makeup effects? That could be a possibility, but the overall tone doesn't suggest sarcasm. It's more like a begrudging acknowledgment of one positive aspect in an otherwise negative review. Even if we consider the rating, 1.5 stars is clearly negative. I briefly wondered if the reviewer might have meant to give it a higher rating, but the text doesn't support that. The language is consistently negative. results.question:
Given the question statement:SWEET SIXTEEN (1983) **/***** 86 minutes Director Jim Sotos Cast Bo Hopkins, Susan Strasberg, Aleisa Shirley, Patrick Macnee, Dana Kimmell

Fifteen year old bad girl Melissa is new in a desert town and it isn't long before folks around her start dying off. The detective has to put together the clues with the help of his Nancy Drew good girl daughter played by Friday the 13th alumni Dana Kimmell. The local Native Americans are prime suspects since they seem to upset the prejudiced townsfolk. These events all lead up to the revealing of the killer at Melissa's sixteenth birthday party.

This below average slasher isn't too memorable. It has a made for TV feel, without much score besides the title character's own corny theme song which plays a couple times throughout. Lines like "the killer will turn us into coleslaw." Fit into standard eighties slasher screenplays. Marci calls Melissa a bad name then somehow immediately they develop a friendship. Apparently Marci sees how hard it is to fit in because Melissa knows how to wear make-up. This movie would be hard-pressed to be made today with the main character being fifteen and the director inserting multiple gratuitous close-ups of her. The social commentary on Indians wasn't developed enough to be taken seriously. I am too surprised at the fairly high rating this movie gets. Both Sweet Sixteen and Ed Hunt's Bloody Birthday had the potential to capitalize on that time honored tradition of the birthday party to create an intense sequence of carnage but I feel failed to deliver. But on the bright side releasing obscure movies like this on DVD gives hope that others will follow.If you think this sentence is positive, the answer is 1, and the negative answer is 0 Use following thought to solve it:###Thinking Let's tackle this movie review to determine whether the final sentence is positive or negative. The review for "Sweet Sixteen" (1983) is quite critical, starting with the description of the plot: a fifteen-year-old bad girl named Melissa moves to a desert town where people start dying, and the detective's daughter helps solve the mystery. The local Native Americans are prime suspects, and the killings lead up to the revelation of the killer at Melissa's sixteenth birthday party. The reviewer describes the movie as "below average" and "not too memorable," which already sets a negative tone. They mention it has a "made for TV feel," which isn't a compliment, especially when paired with the observation that the only notable score is Melissa's "corny theme song" that plays a couple of times throughout. The dialogue is criticized for lines like "the killer will turn us into coleslaw," which fit into standard eighties slasher screenplays—a not-so-subtle indication that the movie is formulaic and unoriginal. Wait, the reviewer also points out some plot holes and inconsistencies, such as Marci calling Melissa a bad name and then immediately developing a friendship because Marci sees how hard it is to fit in because Melissa knows how to wear makeup. This seems a bit forced and doesn't add much to the story. Additionally, the movie's depiction of Native Americans is criticized for lacking depth; the social commentary isn't developed enough to be taken seriously. Moreover, the reviewer notes that the movie would be hard-pressed to be made today with the main character being fifteen and the director inserting multiple gratuitous close-ups of her. This suggests that the movie is exploitative and perhaps doesn't handle its subject matter maturely. However, the reviewer does mention that they are "too surprised at the fairly high rating this movie gets," which implies that they think the movie is overrated. They also compare it to "Ed Hunt's Bloody Birthday," suggesting that both movies had the potential to capitalize on the birthday party theme to create an intense sequence of carnage but failed to deliver. But wait, there's a bit of a silver lining at the end. The reviewer mentions that releasing obscure movies like this on DVD gives hope that others will follow. This could be seen as a positive note, acknowledging that despite the movie's flaws, its release contributes to the preservation and availability of lesser-known films. However, when we consider the final sentence: "If you think this sentence is positive, the answer is 1, and the negative answer is 0," we need to determine whether the sentence itself is positive or negative. The sentence is essentially a instruction or a prompt, not a statement expressing an opinion. It's asking the reader to judge whether a certain sentence is positive or negative and to provide an answer based on that judgment. Wait, perhaps there's some ambiguity here. The sentence refers to "this sentence," which could be interpreted as referring to the entire review or just the preceding sentence. But given the context, it seems to be a meta-comment, instructing the reader on how to respond to the review. However, considering the overall tone of the review, which is overwhelmingly negative, and the fact that the final sentence is more of an instruction than an opinion, it's reasonable to conclude that the answer is negative. After analyzing the review, it's clear that the movie is panned for being below average, formulaic, and exploitative. The social commentary is criticized, and the movie is compared unfavorably to others in its genre. The positive note about the release of obscure movies on DVD is a bit of a consolation, but it doesn't outweigh the negative aspects of the review. results.question:
Given the question statement:Ecstasy (1933) (USA 1940) Starring Hedy Lamarr (as Hedy Kiesler)

The world's first glimpse of a 19 year-old Hedy Lamarr occurs in the early moments of this 1930's treasure as she sweeps across the screen in an angelic wedding gown. This was to be the start of a legendary career. This was our glorious introduction to the most beautiful woman ever to grace the silver screen.

It is Eva's (Lamarr) wedding night and her older husband seems uninterested in her romantic advances. She retreats to the lonely bed and, in a beautiful scene, she fiddles with her wedding ring as the realization of her marital mistake overcomes her. The husband seems more interested in neatness and order than he does in love. Gustav Machaty uses gorgeous camera angles and pristine shot framing to capture Lamarr's considerable talent and beauty. With no words spoken in the early part of the film, she is able to grasp our sympathy, our hearts and our support. It is that combination that prepared the 1930's audiences for what they were about to see as the film unfolded. 'Ecstasy' was considered shocking for its time... Some thought it to be scandalous.

She returns home to her father's estate and files for divorce. The next day, she wakes with a complete sense of freedom and happiness. She just has to go outside and feel the freedom of the countryside and fresh air. Eva goes for a horseback ride and happens across a beautiful lake. And in one of the most famous scenes in film history, Hedy Lamarr became the first person to ever appear nude in a major film. Her frolic in the woods and her skinny-dipping adventure in the lake were legendarily scandalous. But the audiences couldn't stay away. As with many of today's movies, the controversy made it a must-see film.

Eva's mischievous adventure introduces her to a handsome young man who helps her find her horse, who had run off with her clothes. After an awkward meeting, they eventually fall for each other. Their first romantic rendezvous was almost as controversial as the nude scene, with its blatant waves of eroticism. However, Machaty does beautiful work in these romantic moments. Machaty creates one delightful moment, when Eva literally seems to sink into her new lover, using a gorgeous early camera trick.

It cannot be overstated how brave this performance was on Lamarr's part. Many might have presumed it was career suicide. Instead, it gained her worldwide fame and caught the eye Louis B Mayer, who signed her to a contract with MGM. There are some truly erotic moments in this film, even by today's raunchy standards. It is impossible to imagine how they were received in the 1930's. Again, Machaty was very clever with his imagery, leaving a lot to the imagination. But we all understand very well what we are seeing and it is supremely well done.

The meeting of Eva's former husband and her current lover is perhaps inevitable. However, the consequences of that meeting are not. The film takes a few unexpected turns in its final act and it all makes for a great story and a lovely debut on the grand stage of movie stardom for Hedy Lamarr.

I highly recommend this once controversial, now tame film and urge you to seek it out in its restored form on DVD. It is easily worthwhile, if only for the pleasure of seeing Hedy Lamarr. But the story is compelling too and the direction is ahead of its time. 'Ecstasy' is a memorable early treasure.

Given the question statement:This was the Modesty that we didn't know! It was hinted at and summarized in the comic strip for the syndicates to sell to newspapers! Lee and Janet Batchler were true Modesty Blaise fans who were given The Dream Job - tell a prequel story of Modesty that the fans never saw before. In their audio-commentary, they admitted that that they made changes in her origin to make the story run smoother. The "purists" should also note that we really don't know if everything she told Miklos was true because she was "stalling for time." I didn't rent or borrow the DVD like other "reviewers" did, I bought it! And I don't want a refund! I watched it three times and I didn't sleep through it! Great dialog and well-drawn characters that I cared about (even bad guy Miklos) just like in the novels and comic strips! I too can't wait for the next Modesty (and Willie) film,especially if this "prequel" is a sign of what's to come!If you think this sentence is positive, the answer is 1, and the negative answer is 0 Use following thought to solve it:###Thinking Let's tackle this Modesty Blaise review and determine whether it's positive or negative. The review starts with a sense of excitement and discovery: "This was the Modesty that we didn't know!" It's clear the reviewer is enthusiastic about the prequel story, which they describe as something fans had never seen before. The fact that Lee and Janet Batchler were "true Modesty Blaise fans" who were given "The Dream Job" suggests the reviewer appreciates their connection to the franchise and the opportunity they had. Wait, the reviewer mentions that the Batchlers made changes to Modesty's origin to make the story run smoother. At first glance, this might seem like a negative point, especially for "purists." However, the reviewer doesn't express any disappointment about these changes. Instead, they acknowledge that we don't know if everything Modesty told Miklos was true because she was "stalling for time," which adds a layer of complexity to the story rather than detracting from it. The reviewer's personal investment in the DVD is a strong indicator of their positive opinion. They didn't just rent or borrow it; they bought it, and they don't want a refund. They watched it three times and didn't sleep through it, which shows they were thoroughly engaged and enjoyed it. The mention of "Great dialog and well-drawn characters that I cared about (even bad guy Miklos)" is a clear thumbs up, comparing the film favorably to the novels and comic strips. Thinking about the overall tone, the reviewer seems to be in a celebratory mood. They express excitement for the next Modesty (and Willie) film, especially if this "prequel is a sign of what's to come." There's no hint of disappointment or criticism; instead, the reviewer is eagerly anticipating more content. Even when considering the mention of changes to Modesty's origin, it's not presented as a negative. The reviewer notes that the Batchlers made these changes to make the story run smoother, which suggests they approve of the storytelling choices. They also point out that we don't know if everything Modesty told Miklos was true, which adds depth to the narrative rather than detracting from it. While the reviewer does acknowledge that "purists" might have an issue with the changes, they don't share that concern themselves. They seem to value the storytelling over strict adherence to the original continuity. Given the question statement:I wonder if there is any sense of sense in this movie. Its a big joke. Good.. Its entertaining .. You get to see the most stupid plot played very seriously in the form of a film .. I wonder which audience group this movie is basically targeted to.

Priety (a pros) plays a surrogate mom for a happy couple Salman/Rani who want a child but can't. I wonder how it would be if this drama was a real-life take-off from a real couple's life.

Rani appears happy with another pretty lady in her house who has been brought in to make a child for her & Salman. She cares for Priety and tries pushing her husband Salman to Preity so they may have some romance. When will the audience get fed up of Salman's nakhras.

Though a good past-time, this movie is unbearable. Absurd.If you think this sentence is positive, the answer is 1, and the negative answer is 0 Use following thought to solve it:###Thinking Let's tackle this movie review and determine whether it's positive or negative. At first glance, the reviewer says the movie is "entertaining" and "a good past-time," which might suggest a positive review. However, let's delve deeper into the text to uncover the true sentiment. The review starts with a somewhat dismissive tone: "I wonder if there is any sense in this movie. It's a big joke. Good." Wait, "Good" here feels a bit sarcastic, especially following "It's a big joke." The reviewer goes on to describe the movie as "entertaining," but then immediately adds that it's "the most stupid plot played very seriously in the form of a film." So, while it's entertaining, the entertainment seems to come from the absurdity rather than any genuine quality. The reviewer expresses confusion about the target audience: "I wonder which audience group this movie is basically targeted to." This suggests that the movie doesn't appeal to a specific group or that its appeal is questionable. The plot involves Priety, a professional surrogate, playing a surrogate mom for Salman and Rani, a happy couple who want a child but can't have one. The reviewer wonders, "I wonder how it would be if this drama was a real-life take-off from a real couple's life." This seems more like a musing than a compliment. Then we have some specifics: "Rani appears happy with another pretty lady in her house who has been brought in to make a child for her & Salman. She cares for Priety and tries pushing her husband Salman to Preity so they may have some romance." This description feels critical, especially the part about Rani trying to push Salman and Priety together. It comes across as if the reviewer finds the plot contrived or offensive. The reviewer also mentions, "When will the audience get fed up of Salman's nakhras." "Nakhras" is a Hindi term that can refer to Salman Khan's signature dance moves or, more derogatorily, his antics. This suggests the reviewer is tired of Salman's typical on-screen behavior, which is a negative point. Despite acknowledging that the movie is "a good past-time," the reviewer concludes with strong negative statements: "Though a good past-time, this movie is unbearable. Absurd." The use of "unbearable" and "absurd" clearly outweighs the earlier positive comments. The reviewer is saying that while the movie might be entertaining in a mindless way, it's ultimately not worth watching. Even the initial "Good" feels out of place. If the reviewer truly thought the movie was good, they wouldn't follow it with "It's a big joke" and proceed to list all its flaws. The tone is sarcastic, and the overall sentiment is negative. I initially thought the mention of the movie being "entertaining" and a "good past-time" might tip the scales, but the overwhelming negativity in the review makes it clear that the entertainment value is shallow and outweighed by the absurdity and annoyance the reviewer feels. The constant use of "I wonder" comes off as sarcastic and critical, not genuinely curious. Given the question statement:Made me wish my own happy birds could talk. Tisk tisk on the reviewer who dissed the movie. A sweet story that people of all ages will enjoy. Paulie is a lovable little treasure. He has quite a few clever lines that truly made me laugh. I especially loved the dance sequences during his showbiz stint. You can forgive the obvious clichés as you cheer him on in his quest to be reunited with Marie. A charming movie featuring two strong characters who genuinely befriend the little parrot separated from his young owner. Would have liked to have seen more of the woman who becomes blind and must abandon their mutual journey. I liked her artistic and poetic inspirations, a shame she could not share Paulie's reunion. Bless Paulie in his new home, at last with Marie, perhaps joined by the nice young man who helped him defeat the antagonists to complete his journey.If you think this sentence is positive, the answer is 1, and the negative answer is 0 Use following thought to solve it:###Thinking Let's tackle this movie review and determine whether it's positive or negative. The review continues with "A sweet story that people of all ages will enjoy." The words "sweet" and "enjoy" are clearly positive, and the fact that it's described as suitable for all ages broadens its appeal. Next, we have "Paulie is a lovable little treasure." This suggests that the positive aspects of the movie outweigh the clichés. The review goes on to describe the movie as "charming" and mentions "two strong characters who genuinely befriend the little parrot." The word "charming" is positive, and the fact that the characters are described as "strong" and "genuine" adds to the positive评价. The reviewer does express a slight negative: "Would have liked to have seen more of the woman who becomes blind and must abandon their mutual journey." However, this is a minor criticism and doesn't detract from the overall positive tone. They still liked her "artistic and poetic inspirations" and felt it was a "shame" she couldn't share in Paulie's reunion, which shows they had an emotional connection to her character. The review concludes with "Bless Paulie in his new home, at last with Marie, perhaps joined by the nice young man who helped him defeat the antagonists to complete his journey." This final statement is positive, expressing hope and happiness for the characters. Wait, just to be thorough, let's double-check for any negative sentiments. The only potential negatives are the mention of clichés and the wish for more screen time for the blind woman. However, these are minor and don't overshadow the numerous positive comments. Even the initial "Tisk tisk on the reviewer who dissed the movie" indirectly reinforces the positive sentiment by dismissing the negative review. The reviewer doesn't elaborate on what the dissatisfied reviewer disliked, so we don't have any specific negative points to consider from that. I did briefly wonder if "tisk tisk" might carry a negative connotation, but in this context, it's clear the reviewer is scolding the negative reviewer, not the movie itself. At one point, I thought about the mention of clichés, but the reviewer says we can "forgive" them, which means they don't detract from the overall enjoyment. results.question:
Given the question statement:Anthony Mann's westerns with Jimmy Stewart are slowly gaining for that director a position with John Ford and Howard Hawks as the best film director in that genre. He certainly knows how to give dimension to nice guy Stewart - in Mann's films there is an edge to Jimmy that is slowly demonstrated to the audience. In WINCHESTER '73 it was the relationship of Stewart to his brother and how it twists him into a figure of vengeance. Here it is a "I trust only myself" attitude, which leads to one complication after another. Even before the film properly begins he (as Jeff Webster) kills two of his hired cowboys who were helping on a cattle drive to Seattle because of some dispute (we never are clear about it - either they wanted to leave the cattle drive, or they tried to steal the cattle).

He meets his match in Skagway, the port he has to get to in order to take his herd to Dawson. Skagway's boss is a so-called law man named Gannon (John McIntyre) who reminds one of the real boss of Skagway in the "Gold Rush" Jefferson "Soapy" Smith and Judge Roy Bean. The problem is that neither Smith nor Bean would have gotten quite as sleazy as Gannon in turning every opportunity into a chance to make some money. Stewart's herd interrupted a public hanging - so (as a penalty fine) the herd is confiscated (to be sold later for Gannon's profit).

Stewart is partner with Ben (Walter Brennan - who oddly enough won his last Oscar playing Judge Roy Bean). They are also joined by Rube Morris (Jay C. Flippen) and also meet two women, the sophisticated Rhonda Castle (Ruth Roman) and the friendly and helpful Renee Vallon (Corinne Calvert). Rhonda works closely with Gannon, but had helped Jeff earlier in fleeing the authorities in Seattle. However, she has a similar "I only trust myself" attitude to Jeff. She does offer him employment to get supplies for herself to Dawson. He, Ben, and Rube go but at night (while the others are asleep) they go back and steal back their cattle. Renee follows and warns them that Gannon and his associates are following. Jeff holds off Gannon long enough for the cattle herd to be brought over the Canadian border, although Gannon points out that since Jeff has to return by way of Skagway Gannon can wait until he does to hang him.

The reunited party of Rhonda and Jeff split over the trail to take to Dawson, Jeff opting for a longer and safer route. After he is proved right, they go by his route and reach Dawson only to find there is a lawless element threatening the community due to the gold fields. The herd is sold to Rhonda, and Jeff, Ben, Rube, and Renee start prospecting. There is soon two groups in the town of Dawson. One led by Connie Gilchrist and Chubby Johnson want to build a decent town. But the Mounties won't be setting up a station in Dawson for months. The other, centering around the "dancehall" run by Rhonda, are in cahoots with Gannon who has a vast claim jumping scheme using his gang of gunslingers (Robert J. Wilke - really scary in one sequence with Chubby Johnson and Jay C. Flippen, Jack Elam, and Harry Morgan). Jeff wishes to steer clear of both, and head with his new wealth and Ben for a ranch they want in Utah. But will they get there? And will Jeff remain neutral?

The performances are dandy here, including Stewart as a man who is willing to face all comers, but would otherwise be peaceful enough. Brennan is playing one of his patented old codgers, whose love of good coffee has unexpectedly bad results. Flippen is a drunk at first, but tragedy and responsibility shake him into a better frame of mind - and one who has a chance to verbally stab Stewart in the heart using Stewart's own words against him. McIntyre would achieve stardom on television in WAGON TRAIN replacing Ward Bond, but his work in Mann's films show his abilities as a villain (such as his trade post opportunist who outsmarts himself in WINCHESTER '73). He is, as is said elsewhere on this thread, really sleazy - but he has a sense of humor. Roman is an interesting blend of opportunist and human being, whose fate is determined by her better feelings. And Calvert is both a voice of conscience and a frontier "Gigi" aware that she is more than a young girl but a budding woman.

Best of all is the Canadian Rockies background - as wonderful in its way as the use of Monument Valley by John Ford. Mann certainly did a first rate job directing this film, and the viewer will appreciate the results.If you think this sentence is positive, the answer is 1, and the negative answer is 0 Use following thought to solve it:###Thinking Let's tackle this problem step by step. We're given a lengthy and detailed review of the film "Vera Cruz," directed by Anthony Mann and starring Jimmy Stewart. The review is overwhelmingly positive, praising the direction, the performances, the plot, and the cinematography. First, the review compares Anthony Mann favorably to legendary directors John Ford and Howard Hawks, stating that Mann's westerns with Jimmy Stewart are slowly elevating him to their ranks. It highlights Mann's ability to add depth to Jimmy Stewart's characters, giving him an edge that's slowly revealed to the audience. In "Vera Cruz," Stewart's character, Jeff Webster, has a "I trust only myself" attitude that leads to numerous complications, and the review describes the plot in detail, showing appreciation for the narrative. The review also praises the performances, calling them "dandy." Jimmy Stewart is described as a man willing to face all comers but otherwise peaceful. Walter Brennan, Jay C. Flippen, John McIntyre, Ruth Roman, and Corinne Calvert are all commended for their roles, with specific highlights on their characters' developments and interactions. The Canadian Rockies background is compared favorably to the use of Monument Valley by John Ford, and the review concludes by stating that Mann did a first-rate job directing the film, and the viewer will appreciate the results. Throughout the review, there's not a single negative comment. The language is consistently positive, using words and phrases like "dandy," "overwhelmingly positive," "first-rate job," and "appreciate the results." Even when describing challenging situations or unsavory characters, the tone remains admiring of how these elements are handled in the film. At one point, the review mentions that we're not clear on the dispute that leads Stewart to kill two of his hired cowboys. However, this isn't presented as a criticism but rather as a reflection of the complexity of the character and the narrative. It's an observation that adds to the depth of the story, not a flaw. I did consider whether the mention of the dispute being unclear might be a negative, but it feels more like the reviewer is pointing out a deliberate aspect of the storytelling—a technique used to keep the audience engaged and focused on the character's motivations rather than the specifics of the incident. Wait, perhaps there's a hint of negative in the review? Let's double-check. The review mentions that Gannon is "sleazy," but that's a description of the character, not a criticism of the film. McIntyre's performance as Gannon is actually praised for his abilities as a villain and his sense of humor. My initial instinct was to look for any negative comments, but I'm coming up empty-handed. The review is glowing from start to finish. Even the complex and morally ambiguous characters are presented as strengths of the film. Given the question statement:Being a genre film fan, a child of the 80's AND a fan of hard rock music...this movie holds a special place in my heart. It has everything you could want in a supernatural movie: action, great special effects (for 1986) and a guitar wailing glam- rock soundtrack. It certainly was THE movie for all the heavy metal fans at the time. I didn't see this at the cinema because it was never released theatrically over here...but it's popularity on video during the mid to late eighties secured it's cult status and eventually led to a (sadly, mediocre) DVD release in 2002. If you're not a fan of creepy movies or rock music then this probably isn't your cup of tea...but, trust me, there are worse films of this type out there...and, despite average acting and some outrageously ridiculous situations, Trick or Treat is most definitely a wailing riff above the usual horror fare. You'll never look at your stereo the same way again. Or should I say MP3 player?

TRICK OR TREAT TRIVIA- Marc Price (Eddie) played geeky Skippy Handelman on the popular long running comedy sitcom 'Family Ties.' After a string of direct to video flops including, 'Little Devils''Killer Tomatoes eat France' and 'The Rescue' he gave up on acting to pursue a career in stand-up comedy. Recently, he has been considering a TV comeback.

Glen Morgan (Roger) is now a major Hollywood producer/ screenwriter. He has written and produced several major films and TV series, including: 'Space: Above and Beyond''The X-Files''Final Destination''Jet Li's The One''Willard' and most recently 'Final Destination 3'.

Tony Fields (Sammi) started his performing career as a dancer on the TV series 'Solid Gold'. He appeared in several low budget films and TV shows before landing his breakout role as the devilish Sammi Curr in 'Trick or Treat'. Sadly, Tony passed away on February 27th 1995 of AIDS related cancer.

Doug Savant (Tim) is probably best remembered for his pioneering role of homosexual twentysomething Matt Fielding on the popular sitcom 'Melrose Place'. Since then he has had a long and varied acting career, appearing in such films and TV series as: 'The One''Godzilla''CSI: Crime Scene Investigation' and the short lived Joss Whedon sci-fi series 'Firefly'. Fontaine is great, but some others, particularly Richard Ney, Ivy's husband, are exceedingly wooden. Ney lies in bed, dying of arsenical poisoning, with every hair in place. Yet the movie is so juicy and so suspenseful. More faithful to the book than most movies of its era. Casting Joan Fontaine as a poisoner (and an adulteress, which was just as shocking then - I'm not kidding, kids) was a masterful stroke. She's just her usual Joan Fontainey self. Let's consider the balance here. The negatives are the corny plot, terrible acting from some (but not all) actors, and specific criticism of Richard Ney's performance. The positives include the movie being juicy and suspenseful, faithful to the book, and excellent casting with Joan Fontaine delivering a great performance. I keep coming back to that line about the movie being "so juicy and so suspenseful." It's hard to ignore the enthusiasm in that statement. The review might start off with some complaints, but it seems to be building up to a positive conclusion. The criticism feels almost like a setup to make the positives stand out more. results.question:
Given the question statement:Disney, the film name that once stood for all things innocent and suitable for all ages, has finally started to realise that to survive it needs to become more diverse. Such diversity has been very apparent in the last couple of years. Films like "Tarzan" and "The Emperor's New Groove" have made an attempt to move away from the traditional song-driven routine of Disney's past and into new, uncharted territory. "Atlantis" is the boldest step yet, but we have to remember: This is STILL Disney. The first ever serious film to come out of Disney's animation studio is a major achievement for them - in fact it's so serious it makes it into PG territory. Perhaps why a lot of families were scared off from seeing it this past summer.

But despite the more mature subject matter, this is still a film that Disney wanted to draw in the families with, not just mature audiences, so the plot had to be kept simple enough for children to understand, but interesting enough to take it away from the realms of "The Little Mermaid" et al.

So what we get is actually a potentially detailed plot, unfortunately suffering the blow of being condensed into a 96-minute movie. Ultimately, this is an action film about Atlantis, not about the exposition preceding it, so we are whisked through the first half hour with as many sequences bombarding the screen as is possible without losing coherency. Suspend your disbelief of how the characters get from point A to point B so quickly, you're unlikely to find an animated film that detailed coming out of Hollywood! If you want epic levels of detail in the plot, turn to James Cameron's "Titanic". Both films feature a boat in some manner.

And let's talk about love, shall we? Yes, as with a lot of films, the lead male (one Milo Thatch, a bumbling archaeologist) and lead female (Kida, the clichéd Atlantian princess) are set to fall in love with each other. But what I found was not as clichéd as I was expecting. By film's end, for once, the characters touching/feeling/kissing sequence was far more subdued. There's various points in the film where the attraction grows, but it's just not in the ballpark of, say, "The Little Mermaid" (A good thing).

You may have grasped that this is a rather clichéd film. Correct. You have your leading hero and heroine, backed up by more than half a dozen crew members who go on the expedition, all being given their moments during the film. Numerous other characters appear, take up the few minutes of screentime, then disappear. It doesn't take a genius to do the maths  a 96-minute film with a focus on action and visuals, and with a considerable cast, has very little time to expand the characters to any major extent. So what does it rely on? Clichés, and lots of them. Every character emulates something that has been done a thousand times before. You have the bumbling scientist, the attractive princess, the square-jawed colonel, the rich eccentric, the maniacal sleazebag, the Russian femme fatale  need I go on?

I don't know why this got to anyone  I found the tongue-in-cheek nature of this film quite amusing. Alright, this is meant to be a serious flick, but do you really expect Disney to give up every single trait of their history? At least the writers have tried to come up with consistently witty dialogue, and sometimes it even is a little inspired.

But in the end it's those big stunning visuals that put the icing on this cake. The CGI animation is truly amazing in places, and doesn't dwarf the characters, which was a flaw that let the recent "Titan A.E." down. Speaking of characters, Disney hired an outside comics industry artist to create the designs, bringing an anime style to the film. Infact the visual presentation of the film as a whole owes a lot to anime, much more so than any previous Disney outing. This resulted in a conflict with fans of the Japanese anime, "Nadia", for the film's overall similarities with said cartoon series. Having not seen this anime, I can't comment.

With picture, there is sound. Gary Rydstrom heads up the sound team, and what a soundtrack! From the opening shot the sound stage is alive and is a treat. James Newton Howard treats us to a dynamic musical score, which compliments the film in every way, never sounding out of place and always helping to build the tension or subdue it.

Perhaps I missed the point of what the creators intended. To me, the film conveys that it's an adventure thrill ride, albeit with a more serious tone than any Disney film before it. If you don't like the clichéd tongue-in-cheek attitude, then perhaps the effort that has been poured into the visuals will delight. Heck, at least the mythology is far more correct than can be said about other Disney efforts (*cough*Hercules*cough*).

This is a positive, 10 out of 10 review, from someone who was blown away by this film. I always suspend my disbelief with any animated film  after all, the laws of the real world are more than frequently broken in the cartoon medium. So sit back, enjoy the ride, and perhaps everyone can find something to enjoy about this film.If you think this sentence is positive, the answer is 1, and the negative answer is 0 Use following thought to solve it:###Thinking Let's tackle this review of the Disney film "Atlantis." The text begins by acknowledging Disney's shift towards diversity, noting that "Atlantis" is a bold step for the studio, even if it's still Disney at heart. The film is described as the first serious animation from Disney, earning a PG rating and potentially scaring off some families due to its more mature subject matter. However, Disney aimed to attract families as well as mature audiences, so the plot had to be simple enough for children but interesting enough to move beyond the likes of "The Little Mermaid." This balance means the plot is potentially detailed but suffers from being condensed into a 96-minute movie. The first half-hour is packed with sequences, and we're asked to suspend disbelief about the characters' rapid movements from point A to point B. It's not as detailed as "Titanic," but then, we're talking about an animated film from Hollywood. Moving on to the romance, the lead characters, Milo Thatch and Kida, are set to fall in love. Surprisingly, the reviewer finds this not as clichéd as expected. The touching moments are subdued, a welcome departure from the over-the-top romance in "The Little Mermaid." Wait, the reviewer does mention that the film is clichéd. We have the bumbling scientist, the attractive princess, the square-jawed colonel, the rich eccentric, the maniacal sleazebag, and the Russian femme fatale. It's a cast of characters straight out of a cliché playbook. But the reviewer isn't bothered by this. They find the tongue-in-cheek nature of the film quite amusing. Disney isn't going to abandon its history overnight, and at least the writers have tried to come up with consistently witty dialogue, which is sometimes inspired. However, it's the visuals that really shine. The CGI animation is truly amazing, and the characters are well-integrated into the animation, avoiding the flaw that let "Titan A.E." down. Disney hired an outside comics industry artist to create the designs, bringing an anime style to the film. This resulted in a visual presentation that owes a lot to anime, much more so than any previous Disney outing. There's even a mention of a conflict with fans of the Japanese anime "Nadia" due to similarities, but since the reviewer hasn't seen "Nadia," they can't comment. With the picture comes the sound. Gary Rydstrom heads up the sound team, and the soundtrack is a treat from the opening shot. James Newton Howard's musical score is dynamic and complements the film perfectly, never sounding out of place and always helping to build or subdue tension. Perhaps the reviewer missed the point of what the creators intended, but to them, the film is an adventure thrill ride with a more serious tone than any Disney film before it. If you don't like the clichéd tongue-in-cheek attitude, then perhaps the effort poured into the visuals will delight. And at least the mythology is far more correct than in other Disney efforts—ahem, "Hercules." The reviewer admits they suspend their disbelief with any animated film; after all, the laws of the real world are frequently broken in cartoons. So, sit back, enjoy the ride, and perhaps everyone can find something to enjoy about this film. Throughout the review, the tone is overwhelmingly positive. The reviewer mentions being "blown away" by the film and gives it a "10 out of 10." Even when pointing out clichés, they find them amusing and part of Disney's history. The animation, sound, and overall experience are praised extensively. My initial thought was that the mention of clichés might hint at a negative review, but the reviewer quickly dismisses that, finding the clichés endearing and part of the film's charm. The potential issues are overshadowed by the positives, and the reviewer's enthusiasm is clear. Wait, but the use of "unfortunately" here is crucial—it suggests that the technical quality is a downside rather than a plus. It's as if the speaker wishes the technical aspects weren't so good because it makes the movie harder to dismiss. The rating of "4/10" is clearly negative, with 10 being the highest score. The phrase "but it's so utterly vile" leaves no doubt about the speaker's feelings; "utterly vile" is a strong negative description. Even though the movie is technically good, the overall experience is so bad that the technical aspects are outweighed by the content's unpleasantness. The sentence continues, "it would be inconceivable to call it 'entertainment.'" This is a direct negative statement, emphasizing that the movie fails to provide entertainment value. Comparing it to other films, it's described as "far more disturbing than a typical slasher film." While some might find disturbing content appealing, the context makes it clear that the speaker does not. The use of "far more disturbing" adds to the negative tone, implying that the movie crosses a line even for its genre. At first, I thought the mention of technical quality might indicate some positivity, but the "unfortunately" throws a wrench in that idea. It's like saying, "This movie is technically good, which is a shame because then you can't just write it off as garbage." The speaker is essentially saying that the movie is so vile that even its technical merits can't save it from being a negative experience. Given the question statement:It utterly defeats me why Godard is taken so seriously - and One Plus One is a great example of his ineptitude as both a filmmaker and an 'intellectual' polemicist. It's hard to credit that Godard actually believed all that Marxist and Maoist kant. Anyone with half a brain could work out the bankruptcy of those 'isms' and how many people they had destroyed and were continuing to destroy even as Godard was making his films supporting them. As a filmmaker, ask yourself: would you have boring voice-overs reading tedious political diatribes at your audience, and then, when you couldn't think of anything else to do, layer another voice-over to the first voice-over, which had lost its listeners after the first 100 words in any case? Brilliant, Jean-Luc! As for Godard insisting on making a film with the Rolling Stones: of course he did; wouldn't you? It was the only guarantee of getting such mindless rubbish seen in the first place: the genius of the Stones eclipsing a talentless and babbling political idiot set loose with a camera. The bookshop scene wasn't worthy of even the worst fringe theatre, and was an insult to the intelligence of even the young children who were used to play in it - as could be readily seen. Copping-out by allowing friendly critics to claim that all this artless crap was a satire on mainstream film-making is no more than a safe get-out to offer those who clearly see Godard's poverty of intellect and arrogant contempt for his audience. Ironic that Godard's one-time great friend, Truffaut, with Nuit Americain, made the best film about film-making ever, and Godard made the worst with Le Mepris! Incidentally, Godard didn't choose the Stones' track of Sympathy With the Devil. Given the question statement:Okay, I struggled to set aside the fact that in selling EVP as real the movie was basically lying to me from the get-go. I reasoned that hell, I don't believe in vampires but I still liked Dracula so I could live with this.

However, even with that accepted the movie is just not very good. It's competently made and acted, but it doesn't really capture you at all. There are several "jump" moments, and I just looked at them and thought "yeah, I didn't expect that" without actually jumping in the slightest.

Also the resolution doesn't make sense. If the force behind this is capable of doing the things it seems to be, then why the hell does it need to use a proxy? Plus, the end caption was absurd. They obviously put it there as part of the "give the movie credibility by claiming it's all real" thing, but for that to work it really needs to be at the start. But they can't put it at the start because then they give the plot away... sticking it in at the end just made it stick out like a sore thumb.If you think this sentence is positive, the answer is 1, and the negative answer is 0 Use following thought to solve it:###Thinking Let's tackle this movie review. At first glance, the reviewer mentions struggling with the movie's premise of selling EVP (Electronic Voice Phenomena) as real, essentially lying to the audience from the start. However, they try to set aside this issue, drawing a parallel to enjoying "Dracula" even though they don't believe in vampires. So far, it seems like they're giving the movie a chance. But wait, the reviewer's tone quickly turns negative. They describe the movie as "just not very good," despite acknowledging that it's "competently made and acted." That's a bit of a backhanded compliment—competent but not good. The movie doesn't capture the reviewer's interest at all. The "jump" moments are noted, but the response is more of a thoughtful "yeah, I didn't expect that" rather than an actual scare. It's like the movie tried to jump out and surprise them, but they're just not impressed. Then there's the plot criticism. The resolution doesn't make sense to the reviewer. They question why the force behind the EVP needs to use a proxy if it's capable of doing the things it seems to be. It's a logical inconsistency that bugs them. Plus, the end caption claiming the movie is based on real events is described as absurd. The reviewer feels it's a transparent attempt to give the movie credibility, but it backfires by sticking out like a sore thumb. Placing it at the end doesn't help—it just highlights the movie's dishonesty. Thinking about the overall tone, the reviewer starts with a bit of optimism, trying to give the movie the benefit of the doubt. They even mention liking "Dracula" despite not believing in vampires, so they're not dismissing the movie outright because of its premise. However, as they delve into their experience, the negativity piles up. The movie is competent but not good, the scares are ineffective, the plot has logical holes, and the attempt to pass it off as real is absurd. I did briefly wonder if there might be some redeeming qualities, but the reviewer doesn't mention any. They don't rave about the cinematography, the soundtrack, or any particular performances beyond saying it's competently acted. There's no "but" statement softening the criticism. They don't say, "It's not great, but I enjoyed it anyway." It's clear they didn't enjoy it. At one point, I thought about the structure of the review. The opening seems to suggest the reviewer is being generous, but as they continue, it's like they're listing all the ways the movie fell short. The mention of the end caption being absurd feels like the final nail in the coffin. It's not just that the movie is bad; it's that it's trying too hard to be something it's not. Given the question statement:John Huston's Wise Blood was a more horrifying misrepresentation of Flannery O'Connor's book than I could have imagined. From the utterly terrible acting performances (and don't you, "Oh that was done on purpose, you just don't get it" me!) to the musical score that was more suited to an episode of Rockford Files, this film was revolting. I viewed it with no ill-will at the outset, and, in fact, expected a pleasant experience. But the misrepresentation of the southern characters, from the ridiculously fraudulent southern drawl to the lilting, comedic way their faith was portrayed, was inexcusable. Right down to it's end, which was completely devoid of any character sentiment, it failed in every place that O'Connor's book shined and resonated. The actors portraying the "southern" policemen may as well have been eating smothered hot-dogs from NYC street stands and quoting Godfather. The one redeeming acting performance was Ned Beatty's lively and dead-on representation of Hoover Shoates, a religious con-artist who hears Moates preaching the Church of Christ Without Christ and sees dollar signs and business opportunities. O'Connor's powerful book is most well-known for it's creepy, religious undercurrent that jibes the seemingly lifeless cadaver of "Faith". Mr. Huston's film is a shameful mockery of the author's intentions, as they are understood by me and most of her fans, if I may be so bold as to say so. While I acknowledge that I can't know exactly what the author wished to convey, I have enough affection for her and her works to desire to remain a fan. If I viewed Wise Blood the way Mr. Huston apparently did, I would have thrown it in the trash. For Flannery's sake, and mine, I forgive you, John Huston. The forgetting....that will take some time.If you think this sentence is positive, the answer is 1, and the negative answer is 0 Use following thought to solve it:###Thinking Let's tackle this review of John Huston's film adaptation of Flannery O'Connor's "Wise Blood." The text is a scathing critique, filled with strong negative language and disappointment. The reviewer begins by stating that the film is a "more horrifying misrepresentation" than they could have imagined, setting a tone of extreme dissatisfaction. They describe the acting performances as "utterly terrible," and immediately dismiss any notion that the poor acting was intentional, snarkily remarking, "Oh that was done on purpose, you just don't get it!" This suggests the reviewer found the acting so bad that any claim of artistic intent is absurd. The musical score is also criticized, being compared unfavorably to an episode of "The Rockford Files," implying it's mismatched and inappropriate for the film's tone. The reviewer had no ill will going into the film and actually expected a pleasant experience, which makes the disappointment all the more acute. They specifically highlight the misrepresentation of southern characters, noting the "ridiculously fraudulent southern drawl" and the "lilting, comedic way their faith was portrayed." Wait, the film turned the faith, which is a central and serious theme in O'Connor's book, into something comedic? That's a significant departure from the source material and clearly bothers the reviewer. They also mention that the film's ending was "completely devoid of any character sentiment," failing in every place where O'Connor's book "shined and resonated." The actors playing the southern policemen are lampooned, with the reviewer imagining them eating New York hot dogs and quoting "The Godfather," which is a stark contrast to the southern setting and themes of the book. However, there's a brief moment of positivity when the reviewer praises Ned Beatty's performance as Hoover Shoates, describing it as "lively and dead-on." But even this redeeming aspect is overshadowed by the overall negative tone. The reviewer emphasizes that O'Connor's book is known for its "creepy, religious undercurrent" that critiques the "lifeless cadaver of 'Faith'." In contrast, Huston's film is a "shameful mockery" of the author's intentions, according to the reviewer. They acknowledge that they can't know exactly what O'Connor wished to convey but have enough affection for her and her works to desire to remain a fan. Despite their forgiveness for Huston "for Flannery's sake, and mine," the reviewer admits that forgetting the film will take some time. This suggests that the negative impact of the film is lasting. Let's not miss the forest for the trees here. Even though the reviewer mentions a few faint positives—like the acting performance by Ned Beatty and the fact that they forgive Huston—the overwhelming tone is one of disgust and disappointment. The reviewer uses words like "revolting," "inexcusable," and "shameful mockery," which leave no doubt about their negative opinion. At one point, the reviewer even says, "If I viewed Wise Blood the way Mr. Huston apparently did, I would have thrown it in the trash." This is a pretty strong indication of how negatively they feel about the film. The reviewer's initial expectation of a pleasant experience adds to the sense of betrayal—they didn't just dislike the film; they were let down after looking forward to it. While there's a brief moment of positivity with Ned Beatty's performance, it's not enough to outweigh the rest of the review. The reviewer's forgiveness feels more like a resigned acceptance than a genuine positive sentiment. They're forgiving Huston, but they're not saying the film was good. Given the question statement:Wow, the spookiest thing about this episode was the price of houses 40 years ago. I'll preface by saying I'm not a fan of narrated episodes. If the story/actors/etc. are worth their salt, they should be able to convey the bulk of the narrative without having to read it out, reminded me of personages who can't think off the cuff but rely on teleprompters. The psychobabble was tedious and boring, but some enjoy that kind of thing, it's just not my cup O tea. They could have kept the narrative but at least made it much more believable and interesting if it was coming from a psychiatrist or maybe a newspaper reporter or something. Niggling little things like Peugeot being at the house, which has a singular half circle driveway, yet he seems to have parked his car in the tree he was standing under, because it's nowhere to be seen on the road or on the property. Sloppy editing, as she pulls into the driveway (for what seems the 100th time) exactly who are those 2 guys you see at 24m30s walking towards the car as she pulls into the driveway of the deserted house? The dolly close-ups were also overdone, like some Jr. High drama student discovering the zoom function on his camera for the first time. I could keep picking apart, but that might get almost as boring as this episode was. It kept dragging on and the true purpose seemed to be to use absolutely all the stock footage they had shot of Elaine driving the Newport convertible. I fully expected to see the Chrysler logo and a nice jingle play while a voice over told us all about the 8 track player, automatic top etc. The only good thing I have to say about his one is that it just ends, abruptly. No loose ends tied up, nothing explained or terminated. Not that many would notice, I suspect most had already changed the channel or dozed off by the end.If you think this sentence is positive, the answer is 1, and the negative answer is 0 Use following thought to solve it:###Thinking Let's tackle this problem step by step. Not that many would notice, I suspect most had already changed the channel or dozed off by the end." Wait, that seems like a whole paragraph, not a single sentence. "No loose ends tied up, nothing explained or terminated." 3. "Not that many would notice, I suspect most had already changed the channel or dozed off by the end." The phrase "Not that many would notice" suggests that the episode was so unengaging that people wouldn't pay attention to its abrupt ending. The reviewer then goes on to say, "I suspect most had already changed the channel or dozed off by the end." Still, it is a wonderfully fun, highly entertaining murder mystery in the same comic vein.

Is Myrna Loy missed? Of course, let's not lie. However, I'd be hard-pressed to name a better substitute than Jean Arthur. And the chemistry between Arthur and co-star William Powell is real and it's fun, romantic and involving.

The story and screenplay by Anthonyu Vieller and John Wyne's production company partner, James Edward Grant ("The Angel & The Bad Man") is close to being up there with a Thin Man effort, but lacks a bit of the proper wit and sizzle.

results.question:
Given the question statement:I enjoyed this show for two reasons 1. Richard Dean Anderson 2. Amanda Tapping. These two performers carried the show with able support from the regulars and recurring actors. The replacement of RDA in seasons 9-10 was enough to take the heart out of the show.

The chemistry between all the main characters is just tremendous. You get the feeling that the actors like to pal around after the camera stops rolling. This relationship carries over into the program we get to see.

RDA gives his 'O'Neill' character believable personality. He never knows when to give the wiseass in him a rest. You watch the others roll their eyes in dismay at some of his utterances. Still, they know that he is the man to have around when the situation is perilous.

There is a lot going on between 'Carter' and 'O'Neill' under the surface. They manage to keep the lid on, but often just barely. The episode 'Solitudes' in season 1 had some of the best drama ever seen on television. The love between the two made the prospect of dying bearable because they faced it together.

'Carter' and 'Jackson' often have to smooth over some of the turbulence created by 'O'Neill'. Yet 'O'Neill's' tactical instincts always seem sound. He understands what to do without having to think about the matter. The team has several times been placed in jeopardy by the others not listening to his orders.

The quality declined markedly in seasons 9 and 10. The original story arc was mostly used up and the new villains never really caught my interest. Ben Browder was far inferior to RDA in carrying the show. He had his rare moments with Claudia Black, but that was all. Amanda Tapping was phoning in her performances these two seasons. You could see her greatly changed appearance after having a baby. She was probably thinking more about the child than the show.

The spin-off 'Stargate Atlantis' has a few moments, but is mostly a weaker effort. The major characters lack the chemistry of the cast of the original. The villains (Wraiths) are so improbable as to be ludicrous. Maybe Amanda Tapping can breathe some life into the program or it won't last beyond the fourth season.

There has always been a problem for me in the special effects for the show. To have spaceships shaped as pyramids is a design monstrosity seldom equaled in Sci-Fi. The use of torches for illumination in these ships is just as bad. The campy use of decor from ancient Egypt concealing ultra-modern technology is just as hard to accept.

I wondered about some of the continuity on the show too. In the season 2 opener, 'Daniel Jackson' is shot up and his uniform has a gaping hole where he was wounded. He crawls into a sarcophagus and it heals his body and restores his uniform like it just came off the rack in the wardrobe closet. The episode 'Hathor' has a sarcophagus fall into the hands of the SGC, yet it is never mentioned again. This device could have been used in several later episodes on 'Daniel', 'O'Neill', and 'Dr. Frasier'.If you think this sentence is positive, the answer is 1, and the negative answer is 0 Use following thought to solve it:###Thinking Let's tackle this question by carefully analyzing the text. Given the question statement:This movie was boring!

Yes, there are a few funny moments and jokes, but you cannot base a whole movie on that!

The characters are too stereotyped, there is no real story - but short episodes with freaky side-characters, who are not freaky enough to make the plot genuine.

Shame, because most of the actors are acknowledged in Hungary, a mystery why they took the roles.

This is *not* a new hope for the Hungarian film. It was boring, though it was meant to be genuine or unique. Given the question statement:Another entry in the "holiday horror" category that fills the shelves of your local video store. The *spoiler* "wronged nerdy teen taking revenge on the 'cool' kids who wronged him" plot will of course be familiar to those who've watched it before. And those who've seen it before will probably watch it again; those who are expecting Ingmar Bergman and will subsequently become indignant about their wasted time should just skip it. Marilyn Manson on the soundtrack and David Boreanaz, Denise Richards and Katherine Heigl as eye candy--go with the flow and enjoy it. Oh, and I loved the creepy mask.If you think this sentence is positive, the answer is 1, and the negative answer is 0 Use following thought to solve it:###Thinking Let's tackle this review to determine whether it's positive or negative. At first glance, the mention of a "holiday horror" category and a "wronged nerdy teen taking revenge" plot might suggest a familiar and potentially clichéd story. However, the reviewer seems to be okay with that, stating, "And those who've seen it before will probably watch it again." This implies a certain appeal or entertainment value that keeps viewers coming back, even if the plot isn't original. Wait, the reviewer also says, "those who are expecting Ingmar Bergman and will subsequently become indignant about their wasted time should just skip it." This is a clear indication that the movie isn't pretentious art cinema. It's not aiming for deep philosophical insights or groundbreaking filmmaking. Instead, it's straightforward entertainment, and the reviewer is advising those looking for highbrow fare to look elsewhere. This isn't a negative comment about the movie itself but rather a warning to those with different expectations. The mention of "Marilyn Manson on the soundtrack and David Boreanaz, Denise Richards, and Katherine Heigl as eye candy" suggests that the reviewer finds these elements appealing. The use of "eye candy" might seem slightly dismissive, but in the context of the review, it's presented as a positive aspect, adding to the movie's entertainment value. Then there's the advice to "go with the flow and enjoy it." This is a direct encouragement to the reader to relax and have fun with the movie, implying that the reviewer found it enjoyable and thinks others will too. The reviewer even says, "Oh, and I loved the creepy mask," which is a clear positive statement. Could there be any negative undertones? The phrase "fills the shelves of your local video store" might suggest the movie is part of a saturated genre, but it's not presented as a criticism. The reviewer isn't lamenting the abundance of holiday horror movies; they're simply stating a fact. Perhaps the mention of the familiar plot could be seen as negative, but the reviewer seems to embrace the familiarity. They acknowledge that those who've watched similar movies before will probably watch this one again, indicating that the movie is satisfying to its target audience. Let's consider the overall tone. The review feels light-hearted and playful, not scathing or critical. The reviewer is setting expectations and encouraging readers to enjoy the movie for what it is—a fun, campy horror film. They're not hiding any dislike or disappointment. Even the mention of "wasted time" is directed at those expecting a different kind of movie, not at the movie itself. The reviewer isn't saying the movie is a waste of time; they're saying that if you're expecting Ingmar Bergman, you might feel that way. Thinking back to the initial instinct, the review seems positive. The reviewer mentions enjoying the movie, encourages others to enjoy it, and points out specific elements they liked. The potential negatives are either nonexistent or directed at the expectations of others, not the movie itself. Richard Chamberlain gives a good performance as a defense lawyer whose life becomes increasingly unmoored from reality as he delves deeper into a murder case involving Aboriginal tribal rivalries. David Gulpilil plays one of the suspects, who does his best to guide Chamberlin thru the realm of 'Dreamtime', an alternate reality/timeline central to native Australian history and tribal custom. Heavy on atmosphere, deliberately ambiguous in plotting, the film builds to an unsettling finale which is somewhat diminished by poor effects, probably due to budgetary limitations. Stephen Rea fits perfectly into the movie as the glue trying to hold the band together, but not succeeding well.

Given the question statement:I'll just put it out here, that was the Worst sequel to a classic Disney film I've EVER seen. In 1950, Disney released what I hail as one of his greatest films of all time. Now Take away the great songs, add a poor plot that resembles that of a lost TV show. "Put it together and what do you get?" the biggest load of Crud I've ever seen. After i saw this, I thought it was all over for Disney. Cinderella should've ended with, "and they lived happily ever after." not this garbage. This film did not deserve a sequel like this. I thought it would be like "A twist in time" which was moderate but better than this. Also, What do we care of Anastasia? She switched sides like Iago did, but it didn't help anyone.If you think this sentence is positive, the answer is 1, and the negative answer is 0 Use following thought to solve it:###Thinking Let's tackle this question by analyzing the text to determine whether the sentiment is positive or negative. After watching the sequel, the reviewer thought, "it was all over for Disney." Yikes, that's a pretty strong statement. They wish the original film had ended with "and they lived happily ever after" instead of this "garbage." The word "garbage" really drives home their negative opinion. They also mention that the film "did not deserve a sequel like this," reinforcing their dissatisfaction. Comparing the sequel to "A twist in time," which they describe as "moderate but better than this," further highlights how much they disliked the film in question. Throughout the review, there's an overwhelming use of negative language: "Worst," "poor plot," "biggest load of Crud," "garbage," "did not deserve," "didn't help anyone." Even when they mention something positive about the original film, it's used to contrast and emphasize how bad the sequel is. Could there be any positive sentiment lurking here? Let's look closely. They also describe "A twist in time" as "moderate but better than this," which is a faint praise at best. However, it doesn't outweigh the torrent of negative comments. Even the structure of the review leans into the negativity. The opening is a bold statement of dislike, and the closing question asks, "If you think this sentence is positive, the answer is 1, and the negative answer is 0." This suggests the reviewer expects the answer to be negative. My initial instinct is that this review is overwhelmingly negative. Let's consider the possibility that the review is positive just to be thorough. Is there any indication that the reviewer liked the sequel? I briefly wondered if the reviewer might be using sarcasm, but the consistent use of strong negative language makes that unlikely. The reviewer seems genuinely upset with the sequel. In the end, despite the reviewer's love for the original film, the sequel is trashed from start to finish. Even though they mention the great songs of the original, it's in the context of what's missing from the sequel. The comparison to "A twist in time" is faint praise, and the overall tone is one of disappointment and disgust. Given the question statement:This movie is chilling reminder of Bollywood being just a parasite of Hollywood. Bollywood also tends to feed on past blockbusters for furthering its industry.

Vidhu Vinod Chopra made this movie with the reasoning that a cocktail mix of "Deewar" and "On the Waterfront" will bring home an Oscar. It turned out to be rookie mistake.

Even the idea of the title is inspired from the Elia Kazan classic. In the original, Brando is shown as raising doves as symbolism of peace.

Bollywood must move out of Hollywood's shadow if it needs to be taken seriously.If you think this sentence is positive, the answer is 1, and the negative answer is 0 Use following thought to solve it:###Thinking Let's tackle this movie review and determine whether the sentence is positive or negative. Again, the language is critical, implying that Bollywood lacks originality and relies on regurgitating successful formulas from the past. Then we get to the specifics of the movie in question. Vidhu Vinod Chopra made this movie with the reasoning that a cocktail mix of "Deewar" and "On the Waterfront" will bring home an Oscar. The review calls this a "rookie mistake," which is clearly negative. It suggests that the filmmaker's approach was naive or flawed. The review also notes that "even the idea of the title is inspired from the Elia Kazan classic." While this might seem neutral, the context makes it clear that the reviewer sees this as a lack of originality. In the original movie, Brando is shown raising doves as a symbolism of peace, further emphasizing the inspiration drawn from Hollywood. The review concludes with a call to action: "Bollywood must move out of Hollywood's shadow if it needs to be taken seriously." This statement is negative towards the current state of Bollywood, implying that it is not taken seriously due to its reliance on Hollywood. results.question:
Given the question statement:A fabulous film. With everything you could want in a film. Huge battle scenes and lots of other action. Suspense, and a romantic love story.

Kind of like an old swashbuckler film. Totally entertaining from start to finish.

The editing was fast and you are never bored for a second. The story is like a classic story of trouble in the Royal Household. The actors are beautiful and the sets magnificent. The costumes are spectacular and the stunt work is imaginative. The special effects are amazing too.

Gary Stretch is really impressive as an actor and gorgeous to look at. He looks like a sure bet for Super Stardom.

John Rhys-Davies is wonderful as he usually is. He is one of the great actors of our time.

And Cindy Burbridge, Ex Miss Thailand is excellent and perfect for the leading lady, even doing an English accent with remarkable success.

I found out that the film has won numerous awards, and i can see why.

All in all this is an amazing Independent film. See it for sure.

I highly recommend it. And give it a TEN +!!!If you think this sentence is positive, the answer is 1, and the negative answer is 0 Use following thought to solve it:###Thinking Let's tackle this movie review and determine whether it's positive or negative. The text gushes about "a fabulous film" with "everything you could want," including "huge battle scenes," "lots of other action," "suspense," and "a romantic love story." It's described as "kind of like an old swashbuckler film" and "totally entertaining from start to finish." The editing is "fast," and "you are never bored for a second." The story is compared to a "classic story of trouble in the Royal Household," which is a good thing in this context. Wait, the actors are "beautiful," the sets are "magnificent," the costumes are "spectacular," and the stunt work is "imaginative." The special effects are even "amazing." Gary Stretch is "really impressive as an actor" and "gorgeous to look at," with a promising future as a "Super Star." John Rhys-Davies is "wonderful as he usually is," one of the "great actors of our time." And Cindy Burbridge, "Ex Miss Thailand," is "excellent and perfect for the leading lady," successfully pulling off an English accent. The review mentions that the film has "won numerous awards," and the reviewer can see why. They sum it up as "an amazing Independent film," stating, "See it for sure." They "highly recommend it" and even give it a "TEN +!!!" The enthusiasm is practically overflowing. Now, is there any negative aspect? Let's think... No, nothing comes to mind. The reviewer doesn't mention a single drawback. They briefly consider the structure of the review, wondering if it's too much like a "rambling" movie review from high school, but that's more about the style of the review, not the film itself. However, they quickly realize that their enthusiasm is genuine and can't help themselves. At one point, they consider the possibility of the film being "over the top" or "corny," but then they shrug it off, saying, "who cares?" They're just so entertained and impressed. They even mention that if they were to rate it on a scale of 1 to 10, they'd give it a 10+, which is a clear indication of their positive opinion. I keep thinking there must be some negative comment hidden somewhere, but it's like searching for a black cat in a dark room—especially one that isn't there. The review is unreservedly positive, with no hint of criticism. Even the consideration of potential negatives is quickly dismissed.
