results.question:
Given the question statement:Another very good Mann flick thanks to the father/son combination of Walter Brennan and Jimmy Stewart. Brennan (Ben Tatum) is often the comedic conscience of either Stewart or Wayne (Red River/ Rio Bravo). He's there to see that the younger man takes the ride fork or bend. "You're wrong Mr. Dunston". Jeff Webster(Stewart) gives off the impression he cares only for himself but it is clear he cannot desert Brennan. John McIntire is excellent as the law of Skagway with due respect for the trappings of justice over the reality of it. Another key theme is helping people and in turn being helped by people. The loner can do neither and suffers for it.

The caption above plays on Tatum's assertion that he can't live without his coffee. This nicotine addiction proves fatal. Probably the first and last time on the screen.

I recommend this film and now own the DVD.If you think this sentence is positive, the answer is 1, and the negative answer is 0 Use following thought to solve it:###Thinking Let's tackle this movie review and determine whether the sentence "I recommend this film and now own the DVD" is positive or negative. First, the review is overwhelmingly positive. It starts by praising the father-son acting combination of Walter Brennan and Jimmy Stewart, describing it as another very good Mann flick. Brennan is portrayed as the comedic conscience, providing guidance for the younger characters. The reviewer mentions that Jeff Webster (Stewart) gives off the impression he cares only for himself but cannot desert Brennan, suggesting a depth to the character and the acting. John McIntire is commended for his performance as the law of Skagway, with the reviewer noting his respect for the trappings of justice over the reality of it. The review also highlights key themes in the film, such as helping people and the consequences of being a loner, which adds to the positive评价 of the movie's content. Wait, the mention of Tatum's nicotine addiction proving fatal might seem like a negative point, but it's actually discussed in the context of the plot and doesn't detract from the overall positive tone. The reviewer even jokes that it's probably the first and last time such an addiction is portrayed on screen, which comes across as lighthearted rather than critical. You could critique the show for having guests like Marc Ecko as a judge... But... Meh. It's entertaining enough to watch and generally the winner deserves the prize.

Oh yeah and I'm bitter John Besh isn't the new Iron Chef...

Ok, well I rented this movie while I was bed ridden hopped up on pain killers, and let me say, It didn't help the film any.

The film is about a man who buys a car as he is going through a midlife crisis, he loves the car more than anything around him, one day his wife decides to borrow the car. Since I don't want to spoil (not that there was anything to spoil) I shall let your imagination figure out the "Zany" (and I use that word lightly) antics that follow.

I had to fight to stay awake through this snore a minute sleeper of a film, and I would like to say that if you are venturing to the movie store and are thinking about being adventurous, please don't, it's a waste of the film it was printed on.

Then again I could be wrong...If you think this sentence is positive, the answer is 1, and the negative answer is 0 Use following thought to solve it:###Thinking Let's tackle this movie review and determine whether the final statement is positive or negative. The reviewer then advises, "if you are venturing to the movie store and are thinking about being adventurous, please don't, it's a waste of the film it was printed on." That's a stinging indictment. They're essentially saying the movie is so bad it's not even worth the celluloid it's made on. Wait, but then comes the twist: "Then again, I could be wrong..." This is a classic rhetorical device used to soften a blow or to invite the reader to consider an alternative perspective. The reviewer seems to be acknowledging that their opinion might be colored by their circumstances—being bedridden and on painkillers. Maybe they're not in the best state to judge the movie fairly. However, just because they could be wrong doesn't mean they are wrong. The overwhelmingly negative tone of the review suggests that, despite the possibility of their judgment being impaired, the movie is still not worth watching. The reviewer's initial assessment—that the movie is terrible—is strong and consistent. Given the question statement:One of the best if not the best rock'n'roll movies ever. And it's not just mindless fun. There really were a lot of clever jokes in it. Of course I love the Ramones. But with all the "anarchy" and the "I hate high school" themes, the film doesn't at all take itself too seriously,which is what's great about it.

I first saw the movie in the Spring of 1980, and I saw it again recently. Since I went to high school in the late 1970's, it made me kind of nostalgic.

Like I said, this film doesn't take itself that seriously and isn't pretentious like so much other teen fare of the seventies, eighties, and nineties. And to speak of, it's not really dirty or disgusting either. Only PG rated. That's rare for a movie in this category. results.question:
Given the question statement:This film is a complete re-imagining of Romeo and Juliet in Tel Aviv and Nablus. The lovers are one from Tel Aviv et the other from Nablus. There is a border between them, and a constant state of war with the Israeli army ever present everywhere and the Palestinian militants everywhere else with their bombs. The situation is bleak enough. We can imagine love in that enormous loveless trap. But the film goes several light years further by imagining the two lovers are gay, Noam from Tel Aviv and Ashraf from Nablus. To be gay is accepted in Tel Aviv. It is off limits in Nablus. The conflict between the two peoples, the two communities is thus doubled with a conflict between two cultures, two ethics. But this could even be livable if the war did not bring some extra dimension. Ashraf's sister is going to get married to a militant activist in Nablus. Ashraf finally tells his sister about his being gay. She cannot accept it but accepts to speak about it later. From the wedding itself the newly married husband sends a commando into Tel Aviv to set up a bomb attack. It takes place in a café in Tel Aviv and one friend of Noam's is severely wounded. Bad enough. The Isareli army sends a commando to Nablus to arrest the person responsible for this attack, but it turns sour and the newly married wife is shot dead in the street. The funeral follows the wedding. The husband and widower volunteers for a suicide bomb attack. Ashraf volunteers to take his place. The exiled lover comes back to Tel Aviv to die and kill a few people to avenge his sister. He arrives at a diner managed by some friends of Noam's. But Noam sees him and gets out to speak to him. Ashraf has moved back to the middle of the street and he detonates his bomb when Noam reaches him in the street. The vengeance reunites the two lovers in death. We thus have the dual conflict but we do not have the Prince of Verona, a neutral character that can impose peace, or even worse the Prince seems to have chosen sides and to be on the side of Israel. The game is entirely false and death is sure on both sides. But the dimension of impossible love is all the stronger because it is redoubled by a play in the film, a play that shows love in Auschwitz, between two prisoners, one wearing a yellow star and the other a pink triangle. This is both strikingly strong and breathtakingly shocking: gay love in Auschwitz. What comes out of the film is that over there in Tel Aviv or Nablus love is impossible. The film is thus a denunciation of the conflict in Palestine that cannot but continue though it has no reason to even exist though it has thousands of reasons to go on. We should never have let Great Britain deal with the region a long time ago. Today we have to find a solution in which no one will be humiliated. This will only be able to succeed if everyone comes together in order to find a lasting solution. But so far everyone is trying to avoid that general confrontation and discussion preferring bilateral manipulations. So suffering will go on and love will be forbidden, of course not sex since children are needed for the war to go on: so let's procreate more and more little soldiers. But love is just an extra-terrestrial concept.

Dr Jacques COULARDEAU, University Paris Dauphine & University Paris 1 Pantheon SorbonneIf you think this sentence is positive, the answer is 1, and the negative answer is 0 Use following thought to solve it:###Thinking Let's tackle this question step by step. The problem presents a lengthy text that is essentially a review of a film—a modern reimagining of Romeo and Juliet set in Tel Aviv and Nablus, with gay lovers caught in the midst of conflict. The wording is a bit ambiguous, but given that the preceding text is a single, long paragraph and the question asks about "this sentence," it's reasonable to interpret "this sentence" as referring to the entire paragraph. Now, we need to determine whether the overall tone of the review is positive or negative. Let's break it down. The review describes a film that reimagines Romeo and Juliet in a highly charged political and cultural context. The lovers, Noam and Ashraf, are gay, which adds another layer of conflict to their relationship. The setting is Tel Aviv and Nablus, with the constant presence of war, Israeli army, and Palestinian militants. The situation is bleak, and the review paints a picture of a love that is doubly cursed by both political and cultural conflicts. The plot unfolds with tragic events: a bomb attack in Tel Aviv, the death of Ashraf's sister, and ultimately the suicide bombing by Ashraf himself, which results in his death and the death of Noam. The reviewer mentions the absence of a neutral character like the Prince of Verona to impose peace, suggesting that the game is entirely false and death is sure on both sides. The review also draws a parallel to a play within the film set in Auschwitz, highlighting the theme of impossible love. The reviewer states that over there in Tel Aviv or Nablus, love is impossible, and the film is a denunciation of the conflict in Palestine that seems endless. Throughout the text, the tone is somber, critical, and despairing. The reviewer expresses frustration with the ongoing conflict and the lack of a peaceful resolution. Given the question statement:On the surface, this is an above-average post-war romantic comedy. Beneath the veneer, it is MGM character actor stunt-casting at its funniest.

The leads are straightforward, but all the secondaries are cast much against type. Margaret Hamilton (aka Wicked Witch of the West), Edward Everett Horton (professional obsessive-compulsive fussbudget), and Sig Ruman (the Marx Brothers' nemesis in _Night In Casablanca_ and the always-wonderful _Night At The Opera_), playing a well-intentioned gang trying to bring the two leads together, instead of driving them apart as their "usual" characters would do.

It also pokes fun at many romantic-comedy conventions, which is another indication that this could be not so much a "straight" romantic comedy, as it is a wry send-up of the many post-war romantic comedies & their 2-dimensional, stock characters.

I've seen it only once, with interruptions, so I can't be positive, but this movie may be one of those that worked better in the context of the time at which it was made, but is less successful now that viewers "see" these secondary characters through a completely different lens. I'm assuming this is the case when I give it 9 stars. This self-aware approach seems to be another positive aspect. However, the reviewer does express a bit of uncertainty. They mention having seen the movie only once, with interruptions, and can't be positive, but they suspect that "this movie may be one of those that worked better in the context of the time at which it was made, but is less successful now that viewers 'see' these secondary characters through a completely different lens." This is a bit of a caveat, but it doesn't necessarily negate their overall positive assessment. The reviewer then clarifies their uncertainty by stating, "I'm assuming this is the case when I give it 9 stars." Nine stars out of ten is a high rating, indicating strong approval. They conclude with the sentence in question: "I thought it was hysterical." Now, could "I thought it was hysterical" be interpreted as negative? The word "hysterical" can sometimes have negative connotations, especially when referring to irrational or uncontrollable emotions. However, in the context of a movie review, "hysterical" is almost always used positively to describe something that is very funny or amusing. My first instinct is that "hysterical" is positive here, but let's be thorough. Is there any reason to think the reviewer might be using "hysterical" sarcastically? Given the question statement:***Comments contain spoilers*** I was barely holding on to this show as appointment TV when they started the annoying music under EVERY SCENE, when Don Epps was averaging almost a shooting per case, when the very nasally Diane Farr was obviously pregnant (but we weren't to notice) and when Colby was a f*****g TRIPLE agent. But now, in tonight's episode,David is trapped with a paranoid, nut job who is an OBVIOUS amateur with a gun, in an elevator and....HE CAN'T DISARM HIM. A trained, experienced field agent who has been 1st through the door many times and is experienced in hand-to-hand fighting, CAN'T TAKE OUT A NUT JOB. Not when said nut job blinks, looks away, drops his head, closes his eyes; not even when he looks up at the fiber optic wire wriggling around the ceiling like a stripper on a pole for 20 seconds.

Then the scene came that let me know that as much as I enjoy learning from the chubby, frumpish but very charming Charles Epps and his sexy sidekick/love interest Amita, my Friday nights will be better spent otherwise engaged. Don gives David the "distress word" that is the code for "The s**t is about to go down"; David is ready, they kill the lights, drop the elevator, startle the nut job and......

David CANNOT DISARM/KILL/BEAT INTO SUBMISSION THE NUT JOB. The bad guy ends up with BOTH GUNS, David ends up SHOT.

I'm done. It's as if the reviewer is saying, "I'm out of here, and I hope whatever remains of the show is enjoyable for others, but it certainly won't be for me." Wait, perhaps the reviewer is being facetious. results.question:
Given the question statement:I was dragged to this movie about four years ago by a French actress friend of mine.

For the first half hour I was sitting in my uncomfortable seat at the New Beverly theater in Hollywood, hating this film, hating myself and even hating the French actress. And then...

I don't know what happened but I was pulled into the film in a way that I hadn't been in years. And this was despite the fact that one of the projectors broke and they had to do each changeover by hand. I was in the theater for close to four hours, but it was worth it.

I believe that great movies pull you inside a world, make you a part of it and then drop you off to talk about with your friends over coffee or a drink. This film did that. It was one of the best filmgoing experiences I have ever had.

However, something significant happens around the halfway mark. The reviewer says, "And then... I don't know what happened but I was pulled into the film in a way that I hadn't been in years." This is a clear turning point. Despite the initial dislikes and the technical issues, they became engrossed in the movie. The phrase "pulled into the film" suggests a powerful emotional connection, and "in a way that I hadn't been in years" emphasizes just how impactful the experience was. The reviewer goes on to describe the film as one that "pulls you inside a world, make[s] you a part of it and then drop[s] you off to talk about with your friends over coffee or a drink." This is high praise, indicating that the movie was engaging, immersive, and thought-provoking. The comparison to "one of the best filmgoing experiences I have ever had" further solidifies the positive评价. Initially, I had a brief moment of doubt. The mention of being "dragged" to the movie and the negative feelings at the start made me wonder if the review might be mixed or even negative. But then I reminded myself to consider the overall arc of the review. The transformation from hate to being pulled in is striking. The negatives are outweighed by the powerful positive experience. I also thought about the technical issues—the projector breaking and the manual changeovers. While these are negatives, the reviewer mentions that "it was worth it," showing that the movie's quality overshadowed any discomfort or inconvenience. The long runtime could be seen as a negative, but the reviewer doesn't focus on it as a complaint; instead, they emphasize that the experience was worthwhile. results.question:
Given the question statement:This was quite possibly the worst movie I have ever seen. I watched it with a large group of friends and after it was over not a one of us understood the plot. Aside from the lack of plot, the acting was atrocious, the "special effects" were not so special, and the writing was absolutely horrible. The movie's only redeeming factor is that it's so incredibly bad that it's quite funny. You can't help but laugh at a zombie being run over while actors are spewing crappy dialogue. I wouldn't recommend this film to anyone looking for a good movie, but it's something that a group of friends can get together and have a good laugh about. It's now a running joke among my friends and I. 1 out of 10.If you think this sentence is positive, the answer is 1, and the negative answer is 0 Use following thought to solve it:###Thinking Let's tackle this movie review step by step to determine whether it's positive or negative. The review starts with a bang: "This was quite possibly the worst movie I have ever seen." That's a pretty strong negative statement right off the bat. The reviewer watched it with a large group of friends, and after it was over, "not a one of us understood the plot." So, the plot is a complete mystery, which is definitely a negative point. Moving on, "Aside from the lack of plot, the acting was atrocious, the 'special effects' were not so special, and the writing was absolutely horrible." Wait, the acting is atrocious, the special effects are subpar, and the writing is horrible. Three more solid negative points. The reviewer even uses air quotes around "special effects" to emphasize how unimpressive they were. This is getting worse by the minute. However, there's a glimmer of something in the next sentence: "The movie's only redeeming factor is that it's so incredibly bad that it's quite funny." Okay, so it's so bad that it's good? The reviewer finds humor in its awfulness. "You can't help but laugh at a zombie being run over while actors are spewing crappy dialogue." So, there's some entertainment value in watching how bad it is. But is this enough to tip the scales to positive? Let's keep reading. "I wouldn't recommend this film to anyone looking for a good movie, but it's something that a group of friends can get together and have a good laugh about." The reviewer explicitly states they wouldn't recommend it to someone seeking a good movie, which is negative. But it's good for a laugh with friends—so there's a bit of positivity there. The review concludes with, "It's now a running joke among my friends and I." So, it's a source of humor and a shared experience, which is positive in a social context. Finally, the reviewer rates it "1 out of 10." One out of ten? That's pretty dismal. Wait, could this be a positive review? The reviewer mentions that the movie is so bad it's funny, and it's a good way to bond with friends. But let's think about it. If the movie were good, the reviewer would probably say something like, "This was the best movie I've ever seen! The plot was engaging, the acting was superb, and the special effects were amazing. I highly recommend it!" Instead, the reviewer is praising the movie's ability to be entertainingly bad. I briefly considered whether this might be a positive review in the style of "praising with faint damns," but the language is consistently negative. The reviewer uses words like "worst," "atrocious," "horrible," and "crappy." Even the "redeeming factor" is that the movie is so bad it's funny, which isn't exactly a glowing recommendation. My initial instinct was that this is a negative review, and while the movie might be entertaining in a so-bad-it's-good way, the overall tone is clearly negative. The reviewer wouldn't recommend it to anyone looking for a good movie, and the rating of 1 out of 10 solidifies this. The fact that it's a running joke among friends doesn't change the fact that the reviewer didn't enjoy the movie in a traditional sense. Trying to find any positive angle, I thought about the "so bad it's good" concept. Maybe the reviewer is saying it's a fun guilty pleasure. But the language just doesn't support that. The reviewer says it's "incredibly bad" and "horrible," which are strong negative words. Even the humor is derived from how bad the movie is, not from any inherent quality. I also considered whether the reviewer might be being sarcastic, but there's no indication of that. The tone is consistent throughout, and the reviewer seems to be serious in their assessment. results.question:
Given the question statement:Years have gone by since Don Wilson used his martial arts expertise to take down a robot who was programmed to destroy him, he's also married to the blonde reporter (Stacie Foster) who led the rebellion in the first film, now a new conspiracy is in the works, one that involves look-alike droids who frame our two heroes, and a corporation looking to rule the world (There is no plot to back any of this up) and Cyber Tracker 2 becomes a virtual replay of the first movie. I admit that I have bought DVDs from the bargain bin that were made by PM, PM was a company that specialized in cheap-jack action flicks (like this) which had tons of explosions, little story and overall nothing but mean edged action. Some of these titles have been (mildly) enjoyable (Last Man Standing and The Sweeper) however Cyber Tracker 2 is stuck with the casting of the charisma-less Don Wilson. When comparing the protagonists of similar PM efforts both Jeff Wincott and C. Thomas Howell are Oscar nominees when compared to Don Wilson. Another telling sign is that this was directed by Richard Pepin who has none of the flair Joseph Merhi seems to have in crafting action sequences that feel much more expensive than their budgets. Then again though both C. Thomas and Wincott are probably more expensive to obtain. Cyber Tracker 2 is a rip off with a capitol R, there are so many steals from better movies (Robocop, Terminator, Universal Soldier to even Halloween III!) that it's almost as if Richard Pepin is trying to infuse a sense of identity to the pedestrian material yet without the intelligent ideas or at least the mindless zip of great action, Cyber Tracker 2 falls flat. There is literally no good idea that isn't borrowed from a better movie and the supporting cast overact. The only exception comes from Tony Burton who is miles better than the material. Also Stacie Foster looks like she could be better with far better material. However Cyber Tracker 2 comes off mainly as noisy, bland and lackluster as its leading man, however with no real martial arts sequences to fall back on, all there is, is lots of cars tipping over and that alone is no substitute for the bankruptcy of ambition expressed here.

*1/2 out of 4-(Poor)If you think this sentence is positive, the answer is 1, and the negative answer is 0 Use following thought to solve it:###Thinking Let's tackle this movie review and determine whether the overall sentiment is positive or negative. The review for "Cyber Tracker 2" is quite scathing, so let's dive into the details. The reviewer starts by summarizing the plot, noting that it's a virtual replay of the first movie and that there's no real plot to back it up. Already, this suggests a lack of originality and substance, which are negative points. They mention that they've bought DVDs from the bargain bin made by PM, a company known for cheap-jack action flicks with tons of explosions, little story, and overall mean-edged action. While they admit that some of these titles have been mildly enjoyable, "Cyber Tracker 2" doesn't seem to fall into that category. The casting of Don Wilson is criticized; he's described as charisma-less, and the reviewer compares him unfavorably to the protagonists of similar PM efforts, Jeff Wincott and C. Thomas Howell, who are said to be Oscar nominees in comparison. Wait, that seems a bit hyperbolic. While Wincott and Howell are respected actors, they're not exactly Oscar nominees. Perhaps the reviewer means they have more star power or charisma than Wilson. Regardless, the comparison is unfavorable to Wilson. The director, Richard Pepin, is also taken to task. The reviewer states that he has none of the flair that Joseph Merhi seems to have in crafting action sequences that feel much more expensive than their budgets. This implies that the action sequences in "Cyber Tracker 2" are subpar and don't deliver the cinematic quality one might expect. The review then points out that the movie is a rip-off with a capital R, stealing from better movies like RoboCop, Terminator, Universal Soldier, and even Halloween III. The reviewer suggests that Pepin is trying to infuse a sense of identity to the pedestrian material, but without the intelligent ideas or at least the mindless zip of great action, "Cyber Tracker 2" falls flat. It's emphasized that there is literally no good idea that isn't borrowed from a better movie, and the supporting cast overacts. The only exceptions mentioned are Tony Burton, who is miles better than the material, and Stacie Foster, who looks like she could be better with far better material. However, these positives are overshadowed by the overall negative tone. The reviewer describes the movie as noisy, bland, and lackluster, much like its leading man. They also note that there are no real martial arts sequences to fall back on, and the abundance of cars tipping over is no substitute for the bankruptcy of ambition expressed in the film. The final rating is *1/2 out of 4, labeled as "Poor." Despite the reviewer's admission that some PM titles have been mildly enjoyable, "Cyber Tracker 2" doesn't seem to offer much beyond noise and overacting. The lack of originality, poor direction, and weak performances all contribute to a thoroughly negative review. Given the question statement:This docu-drama is what you would expect from Richard Attenborough, the man who gave us "Gandhi": beautifully photographed, compellingly casted, well written in the measured, literate manner that Hollywood discarded in the 30's, and scrupulously accurate. It stands out as a genre film, excelling in its portrayal of native American (or, more appropriately for its Canadian setting, "First Nations") culture and standing with "Black Robe" as a wonderfully photographed piece of Canoe Country and its culture (here, circa 1934). This idyllic portrait derives drama from its subject: Archie "Grey Owl" Belaney, a Scot raised in Hastings (England) by maiden aunts who became so obsessed with the "red indian" tales of his childhood that he went to Canada, disappeared into the woods, and became a trapper and adopted son of an Ojibway band. He was a vain man with a habit of marrying and abandoning

Indian brides, none of whom seem to have thought less of him for it, for he was also an extraordinarily charming and picaresque character. One of his wives (one smarter than he, by most accounts) propelled him into fame as a writer and early advocate for protecting the wild country of the North, and this forms the focus of Attenborough's tale. The chemistry between Brosnan and Annie Galipeau (as Grey Owl's wife Pony) is engaging and, if not firey, is nonetheless quite touching. A good film when you need some time from the madding crowd.If you think this sentence is positive, the answer is 1, and the negative answer is 0 Use following thought to solve it:###Thinking Let's tackle this review of the docu-drama directed by Richard Attenborough. This idyllic portrait isn't just scenic; it derives drama from the compelling story of Archie "Grey Owl" Belaney. The narrative of Grey Owl's life is fascinating—born in England, he became so obsessed with "red indian" tales that he moved to Canada, disappeared into the woods, and became a trapper and adopted son of an Ojibway band. The review mentions his checkered personal life, including his habit of marrying and abandoning Indian brides, but balances this with descriptions of him as an "extraordinarily charming and picaresque character." It seems the film doesn't shy away from his flaws, which adds depth to his character. Given the question statement:this film has it all; the deft camera work, reminiscent of martin scorcese, or oliver stone, the tight acting of 'heat', the explosive action of a jerry bruckheimer movie, the witty dialogue of a tarantino script and the epic feel of say, 'the godfather'

the judge reinhold character displays a fiery temperememt, yet also shows real emotional depth and intensity. his performance reminds me of robert de niro's portrayal of jake la motta in raging bull.

the action scenes are truly breathtaking, not since bullit has a movie depicted such high octane, yet stylish car scenes. The special effects push the boundries of technology and filmmaking to their limits. Independance day set the standard that this movie clearly has matched, and greatly surpassed.

overall, great acting from its a list cast (like an oscars night party invitation list!), classy locations, gripping action, and a tight script.If you think this sentence is positive, the answer is 1, and the negative answer is 0 Use following thought to solve it:###Thinking Let's tackle this movie review and determine whether it's positive or negative. The action is described as "explosive" and reminiscent of a Jerry Bruckheimer movie, which are typically big-budget, high-action films. The Judge Reinhold character is praised for displaying both a fiery temperament and real emotional depth and intensity. His performance is compared to Robert De Niro's portrayal of Jake La Motta in 'Raging Bull,' which is one of the most iconic and critically acclaimed performances in cinema. This is high praise indeed. The action scenes are described as "truly breathtaking," with car scenes not seen since 'Bullitt,' another classic film known for its exceptional car chase. The special effects are said to push the boundaries of technology and filmmaking, which is a strong compliment. The reviewer mentions that Independence Day set the standard, and this movie has "clearly matched, and greatly surpassed" it. That's a huge compliment to the film's visual effects and overall production value. The review wraps up by stating that the acting is great from an A-list cast, the locations are classy, the action is gripping, and the script is tight. The overall tone is one of admiration and enthusiasm. I did notice that the review doesn't mention a single negative aspect of the film. There's no criticism of the plot, the pacing, the acting, or any other element. results.question:
Given the question statement:I was expecting this to be the same kind of schlock as the previous Modesty Blaise movie, which is why I left it unwatched for so long, but I was very pleasantly surprised.

Far from being a succession of silly gun battles and car/boat chases, it was an almost thoughtful analysis of how a pretty girl gets to become as hard as nails, with nothing being overstated or over-rationalized.

It's likely that the budgetary constraints actually helped with that: less time and effort was spent on finding ever-stupider ways for stunt men to pretend to die, and more was dedicated to making the movie worth watching. Hell, the biggest gun battle takes place off screen -- and the scene where it is heard is all the better for that background noise, that adds to the suspense -- who's winning? Who's dying?

Alexandra Staden might not be as drop-dead gorgeous as Monica Vitti, but few are, and she certainly has every ounce of class and fire that's needed to make the character work -- and the shape of her face, her hair, and her tall, slender body could have been lifted straight from the comic-strip graphics.

Nikolaj Coaster-Waldau was the perfect choice for a Blaise bad-guy, in that he made the character interesting and enjoyable to watch -- even likable (and I doubt I'd consider taking on many brutal, psychopathic murderers as drinking buddies). I can't think of a single one of Hollywood's "former waiters" who could have pulled the role off that well.

Fortunately, Blaise baddies always die, in the end (no spoilers there!) That's a really good thing, because all the girls who would have spent their time swooning over such a disgustingly handsome and interesting hunk can now pragmatically settle for us ordinary Joes.If you think this sentence is positive, the answer is 1, and the negative answer is 0 Use following thought to solve it:###Thinking Let's tackle this movie review to determine whether the overall sentiment is positive or negative. At first glance, the reviewer mentions they were expecting "schlock" due to the previous Modesty Blaise movie, which made them hesitant to watch this one for a long time. However, they were "very pleasantly surprised," which immediately sets a positive tone. The review goes on to describe the movie as "far from being a succession of silly gun battles and car/boat chases." Instead, it's an "almost thoughtful analysis of how a pretty girl gets to become as hard as nails." The reviewer appreciates that nothing is "overstated or over-rationalized," suggesting a balanced and well-handled narrative. They also credit the budgetary constraints for contributing to the movie's quality. With less time and effort spent on "ever-stupider ways for stunt men to pretend to die," the focus was on making the movie worth watching. This is a positive observation, and the example of the biggest gun battle taking place off-screen adds to the suspense, which the reviewer clearly enjoys. The casting choices receive high praise. Alexandra Staden is commended for having "every ounce of class and fire that's needed to make the character work," and her physical attributes are compared favorably to the comic-strip graphics. Nikolaj Coster-Waldau, despite being described as "disgustingly handsome," is lauded as the "perfect choice" for a Modesty Blaise bad guy. The reviewer finds him interesting, enjoyable to watch, and even "likable," which is quite the compliment for a "brutal, psychopathic murderer." Wait, the reviewer does mention that "Blaise baddies always die, in the end," which might seem negative, but they frame it positively by saying it's "a really good thing." This allows the girls who might have been swooning over the handsome bad guy to "pragmatically settle for us ordinary Joes." While this last bit is a bit of self-deprecating humor, it doesn't detract from the overall positive sentiment. Throughout the review, the language is overwhelmingly positive. The reviewer uses phrases like "very pleasantly surprised," "thoughtful analysis," "makes the movie worth watching," "perfect choice," and "pulled the role off that well." Even when they mention the movie's shortcomings, such as the lack of Monica Vitti's drop-dead gorgeousness, it's in a way that still praises Alexandra Staden's performance. While there's a hint of negativity in the initial expectation of "schlock" and the description of the bad guy as a "brutal, psychopathic murderer," these are outweighed by the numerous positive comments. The reviewer's surprise and delight at the movie's quality are evident throughout. At one point, I did wonder if the mention of "budgetary constraints" might be a negative, but the reviewer actually sees this as a positive, suggesting that less money led to a more focused and better movie. My first instinct was to focus on the positives, and despite a few potentially negative mentions, the overall tone remains upbeat. Given the question statement:A bit quirky and bordering bad taste; but intelligent enough to be worthy of watching. A wheelchair-bound young woman Jane Hatchard(Helena Bonham Carter)is teamed with a reluctant caregiver, Richard(Kenneth Branagh). Richard is an artist that daydreams of human flight. He builds an airplane in his garage and intends to fly it. He wants to resurrect his own troubled life by taking care of the independent, dying Jane, who suffers from an neurological disease that has all but left her speechless and very little motor skills. Wheelchair-bound and full of spirit, her last dying wish is to loose her virginity. She offers herself to Richard, who won't help her directly; but is willing to rob a bank in order to pay a gigolo to do the deed. I found this flick ambitious and humorous. Given the question statement:I have to agree with some of the other comments and even go a step further.

Nothing about this film worked, absolutely nothing. Delmar our central character makes the decision to become a surrogate mother in order to earn enough money to buy a restaurant but along the way fall for a wise ex-jailbird. At the same time her friend Hortense is trying to get her lawyer boyfriend to finally marry her. She also happens to be sleeping with Marlon who is desperately in love with her. Then there's Delmar's brother Jethro who gets involved with a former coke addict, Missy who reveals she was sexually abused by her adopted father. On the sidelines we also have the eccentricmother who has an assortment of equally odd friends, one of whom dies on the couch at the beginning of the film. So far so good but after introducing these characters and story lines addressing life, death, grief and love in the first half, the film simply loses direction.

If the writer had only selected one or two characters and allowed us to follow their stories maybe things would have been fine but equal screen time is given to all with the result that no one story or character is fully developed. For instance, why does Delmar think she will be able to hand over her child in exchange for money, especially when the prospective parents are a creepy bigoted lawyer and his semi alcoholic and depressed wife? Why is Hortense so desperate to marry a man who is a jerk and clearly doesn't love her? How is it Missy manages to kick her coke habit overnight? Is Jethro regularly drawn to women with overwhelming problems, or is Missy the exception? Has Delmar and Jethro's mother always been on the eccentric side, or is it a more recent development? Why is Jethro so keen on Cadillacs that he has one in the middle of his living room? Why did Moses spend years in prison for stealing a car, a relatively minor crime? How does Delmar manage to end up giving birth to Moses' baby when there is no suggestion that they ever had sex?

These questions are posed in the screenplay but sadly are never answered. I can only assume they were answered in the original novel and that is why the writer felt the need to include it all in the script. Big mistake. Losing several subplots especially the Hortense and Marlon story, which adds nothing to the overall film, would have tightened things considerably and allowed more time to develop the Delmar, Jethro and Moses characters who are clearly more central to the plot and underlying themes than anyone else.

Add to that the most pedestrian directing style seen outside of the average soap opera and the result is a huge missed opportunity for all, including Jorja Fox who does her best to rise above the material. I'm not surprised that this appears to have been the director's last film as this effort shows no evidence of a visual style or ability to tell a moving and intelligent story.If you think this sentence is positive, the answer is 1, and the negative answer is 0 Use following thought to solve it:###Thinking Let's tackle this film review and determine whether the final sentence is positive or negative. Given the question statement:I'm not particularly fond of remakes, or to steal the modern jargon "retellings", but this film truly peeved me off. The original Prom Night, while not in my humble estimation a masterpiece, still realized what it was... horror. There are some simple things to remember when making a horror film. Suspense is crucial to maintaining the interest of the audience. Sorry folks, but a white knuckle film this was not! The scares were cheap, and foreshadowed terribly. (A good example of scare which has been done to clichéd excess now, is the cat jumping out of the closet, followed soon there after but a now unexpected appearance by the villain of the film) This film couldn't successfully pull that off, so how could I expect it to fulfill any of the other conventions of horror film. There needs to be a likable hero or heroine. This film doesn't have one. The person I most identified with was the head detective. His calm demeanor, but level headed approach to the escape of a killer was what more films of this ilk should have. Common sense approach to events that occur. (If you're running from an Axe wielding psycho, you turn and sprint in the opposite direction. Not jog, whilst looking back ever three seconds, gaging the killer's progress, only to trip over every branch and inanimate object in your path.) If you friend disappears, you don't go looking for them alone. And if you suspect foul play you tell someone, not investigate yourself. These clichés are tired and well overplayed. results.question:
Given the question statement:Me and my girlfriend, Annette, watched this together and we'll both comment.

Both of us really enjoyed watching this even though it took some liberties with Dicken's work. A lot of Dicken's works are somewhat dark and dreary (including Oliver Twist), but this movie changed all that. It was fun, colourful (both visually and musically), and the characters were more lighthearted.

TRAVIS: Normally, I don't care a lot for musical and dance movies, but the tunes in this production were catchy and lively, and the choreography was awesome.

ANNETTE: That's really saying a lot coming from Travis. I can't emphasise enough how really good the dance numbers were. You can tell, for example, that those boys really worked hard getting the routines down to perfection.

TRAVIS: Three actors really stood out IMO; Nancy (Shani W.), Bill Sykes (Oliver Reed), and Artful Dodger (Jack Wild). Man, that Oliver Reed can really do a good villain. That one scene where you see his eyes thru the mail slot gave me chills down the back...AWESOME. And that kid Jack Wild was a perfect Artful Dodger. And Nancy was fantastic (man, I felt bad when she got killed). She can sing too! Kudos to the casting department on their choices there. I hated the Oliver Twist kid tho. He was just too whiny and wimpy for my taste. (I kept wishing Bill Sikes would drop him off into the mud during the chase scene.) And they shouldn't have had him sing either.

ANNETTE: Acting was truly superb. In addition to the three stars Travis mentioned, I felt Ron Moody (Fagin) did a tremendous job. He was so funny, and at the same time lightly sinister too. The supporting actors were great too. Harry Secombe carried his Mr. Bumble role extremely well. And he has a wonderful singing voice. I saw Mr. Secombe perform in another movie entitled "Davy" where he played an opera singer with pleasing results. The talented Harry Secombe should have been in a lot more movies.

TRAVIS: As I mentioned earlier the story isn't quite true to the book, but IMO it was more robust. This movie was not boring either, as some musicals seem to be. And the continuity kept you moving right along with the characters. The tunes did not detract from the plot or put you to sleep by being too long.

ANNETTE: Any musical movie which Travis watches completely has to be a rare find. And this one is indeed a rare find. It is a very easy-to-watch production which carries the viewer smoothly and enjoyably through to the end. In a day when movies all seem to be effects combined with pretty faces, this was a refreshing interlude.

Our combined rating for this was 8.5 of 10. (We'll round up to 9 in this case.).

TRAVIS: I rated this a 7 mainly because the Oliver Twist kid (Mark L.) irritated me, and his songs were torture to my overly sensitive ears. Otherwise, it was an outstanding movie.

ANNETTE: My rating is a 10. Movies don't get much better than this. And you can tell everyone involved in this production really worked hard to make it what it was...a masterpiece.

Please don't miss this one...even if you normally don't like musicals. It really is a rare treat.If you think this sentence is positive, the answer is 1, and the negative answer is 0 Use following thought to solve it:###Thinking Let's tackle this movie review together. results.question:
Given the question statement:Having grown up in Texas, and less than 15 miles from what used to be Gilley's, I can tell you that this movie is nauseating. The majority of Texans do not live like this movie indicates. The plot is weak, and the fake accents are amusing, and it reinforces the stereotypical image that all Texans are beer drinking, honky-tonkin', rednecks. The horribly fake Texas accents is what kills it for me. True, there is a certain Texas twang to most Texans' accents, but these people overdo it. You can't get someone from New Jersey and Ohio to do Texas accents. It just doesn't work. John Travolta should have stuck to disco-dancing or the 50s. Debra Winger was more convincing as Wonder Girl than she is as a Texan.If you think this sentence is positive, the answer is 1, and the negative answer is 0 Use following thought to solve it:###Thinking Let's tackle this movie review step by step to determine whether it's positive or negative. They also mention that Debra Winger was more convincing as Wonder Girl than as a Texan, which is another negative comment on the acting. Throughout the review, the negative comments far outweigh any potentially positive ones. The reviewer's personal connection to Texas adds weight to their criticisms, and their descriptions are overwhelmingly unfavorable. They don't mention any redeeming qualities of the movie, and their final sentence is a clear indication of their negative opinion. results.question:
Given the question statement:This is probably the best horror film made since Ed Wood died.

I can't spoil the ending, because I have absolutely no idea what happened. I'll try my best, though. There are some kind of lesbian vampires, but they keep swapping bodies, so any character might or might not be the character you're supposed to think it is, or it might be a lesbian vampire.

Sound confusing? It's not as confusing as you might think, since none of the characters make any sense to begin with. There's no plot, no character development, and random people show up, speak a few lines, and then disappear, never to be heard from again. There are also zombies, who are *possibly* the enemies of the vampires, but there's also a dream-within-a-dream kind of sequence in a mental hospital, so maybe none of this actually happened, and it's all the main character's hallucination.

The upside? Both of the lead girls take their shirts off briefly. The special effects are simply mind-boggling (I particularly liked the incredibly slow, awkward fight sequences). Everyone has a really silly Canadian accent, which adds to the general level of hilarity.

Well worth the price of rental. We laughed until we cried.If you think this sentence is positive, the answer is 1, and the negative answer is 0 Use following thought to solve it:###Thinking Let's tackle this question by carefully analyzing the text to determine whether the overall sentiment is positive or negative. The text is a review of a horror film, and at first glance, it seems to be a mixed bag of opinions. The review starts with a bold statement: "This is probably the best horror film made since Ed Wood died." Ed Wood is often referred to as the "world's worst director," so saying this film is the best since his death could be interpreted as a backhanded compliment. It's like saying, "This is the best of the worst," which isn't exactly a glowing endorsement. However, it's not outright negative either—it suggests the film is the top in a low-quality genre. Wait, let's delve deeper. The reviewer mentions they can't spoil the ending because they have absolutely no idea what happened. This is immediately a red flag. It's one thing to have a twisty plot that leaves you guessing, but not understanding the ending at all is usually a sign of a poorly constructed narrative. The confusion continues with the plot involving lesbian vampires swapping bodies, making it impossible to keep track of who is who. The reviewer says, "Sound confusing? It's not as confusing as you might think, since none of the characters make any sense to begin with." Hmm, that's not exactly a compliment. The review goes on to point out that there's no plot, no character development, and random people show up, speak a few lines, and then disappear, never to be heard from again. The mention of zombies and a dream-within-a-dream sequence in a mental hospital adds to the confusion, with the possibility that none of it actually happened and it's all the main character's hallucination. This could be an interesting premise, but the way it's described suggests the execution was lacking. However, the reviewer does mention some upsides. Given the question statement:The worst thing about Crush is not that it's acted pretty bad, or that the plot is virtually non-existent, and it's not even that bad that the camerawork could have been better.

No, the worst part of this movie is that it has a few absolutely brilliant moments that keep you hoping that there are more to come.

But in the end, it's too little, too late. If you are a fan of violin-music and cheap tearjerking scenes of 40+ women crying and hugging and talking about babies and marriage - then by all means, don't miss it.

I myself am not exactly thrilled to see the things listed above in a movie, and as a result I had a pretty horrible time. The few absolutely brilliant jokes can not make up for the rest of it.

The verdict: 4/10. Guilty of wasting my time.

Given the question statement:As Alan Rudolph's "Breakfast of Champions" slides into theaters with little fanfare and much derision it makes me think back to 1996 when Keith Gordon's "Mother Night" came out. Now for all the talk of Kurt Vonnegut being "unfilmable" it's surprising that he has gotten two superb cinematic treatments (the other being "Slaughter-house Five"). "Mother Night" is certainly one of the most underappreciated films of the decade and I cannot understand why. It's brilliant! It stays almost entirely faithful to Vonnegut's book (without being stilted or overly literary) and adds to it a poetry that is purely cinematic. How many film adaptations of any author's work can claim that? Vonnegut himself even puts in a cameo appearance towards the end of the film, and can you ask for a better endorsement than that? Not only is it a beautiful film, it is a beautifully acted, written and directed film and it is among my picks for the top five or so American films of the 1990s. It's a mournful, inspired, surreal masterpiece that does not deserve to be neglected. I would sincerely encourage anyone to see "Mother Night" - it doesn't even take a familiarity with Vonnegut's work to fully appreciate it (as "Slaughter-house Five" sometimes does). It is a powerful, affecting piece of cinema.If you think this sentence is positive, the answer is 1, and the negative answer is 0 Use following thought to solve it:###Thinking Let's tackle this problem. We're given a lengthy text about the movie "Mother Night," and we need to determine whether the sentence "It doesn't even take a familiarity with Vonnegut's work to fully appreciate it (as 'Slaughter-house Five' sometimes does)" is positive or negative. A positive sentence gets a 1, and a negative one gets a 0. First, let's understand the context. The text is a passionate defense of "Mother Night," directed by Keith Gordon and based on Kurt Vonnegut's novel. The author expresses surprise that Vonnegut's works have received such excellent cinematic treatments, considering the common belief that Vonnegut is "unfilmable." They describe "Mother Night" as "brilliant," "beautiful," "beautifully acted, written, and directed," and even a "mournful, inspired, surreal masterpiece." The author laments that it's underappreciated and urges everyone to see it. Now, focusing on the specific sentence in question: "It doesn't even take a familiarity with Vonnegut's work to fully appreciate it (as 'Slaughter-house Five' sometimes does)." Let's break it down. At first glance, the phrase "It doesn't even take a familiarity with Vonnegut's work to fully appreciate it" seems positive. It suggests that "Mother Night" is accessible and enjoyable even for those who aren't familiar with Vonnegut's literary style or themes. This is a compliment to the film's universal appeal and adaptability. But wait, the sentence also includes a parenthetical comparison to "Slaughter-house Five": "(as 'Slaughter-house Five' sometimes does)." This comparison implies that "Slaughter-house Five" might require familiarity with Vonnegut's work to be fully appreciated, whereas "Mother Night" does not. This contrast further emphasizes the accessibility of "Mother Night," making it seem more universally appealing. I did consider whether the comparison might be negative towards "Slaughter-house Five," but the author's overall tone is one of appreciation for both films. They mention that Vonnegut has received "two superb cinematic treatments," including "Slaughter-house Five." The comparison is more about highlighting the strength of "Mother Night" rather than criticizing the other film. I also thought about the structure of the sentence. The use of "doesn't even take" could be seen as minimizing the effort required to appreciate the film, which is a positive attribute. It's not a complaint but a compliment to the film's accessibility. Could the sentence be negative? Perhaps if the author meant to suggest that "Mother Night" is shallow or lacks depth because it doesn't require familiarity with Vonnegut's work, but that's not the case here. The overall context is praising the film's ability to stand on its own, which is a positive quality. Moreover, the author explicitly states that "Mother Night" is a "powerful, affecting piece of cinema" and encourages everyone to see it. This reinforces the positive sentiment. While the sentence does contain a comparison that might seem negative towards "Slaughter-house Five" at first glance, the context makes it clear that the author is highlighting the strengths of "Mother Night." The comparison serves to emphasize how remarkable "Mother Night" is for being accessible to a wider audience without sacrificing its quality. results.question:
Given the question statement:I'm certainly glad that a film was made about Carl Brashear's amazing life story. Coming as it did during the Civil Rights era, Brashear became an inspiration for people of all minority groups not willing to settle for a status expected.

Brashear as played by Cuba Gooding, Jr. leads by example in the conduct of the life he has chosen. Very similar to Jackie Robinson who integrated baseball and made it stick by his character and conduct. As Brashear, Gooding knows that he does not want the sharecropper life that his father Carl Lumbly has and Lumbly makes it real clear to get more out of life than he's gotten.

But while Harry Truman integrated the Armed Services after World War II, the Navy still has its restrictions. A black man can only be a cook or an officer's valet, the real fighting parts are denied him. That's not good enough for Gooding who applies to become a Navy deep sea diver.

Once at the diving school at Bayonne, New Jersey, Gooding gets it all thrown at him, mostly by the Master Chief Petty Officer in charge, Robert DeNiro. DeNiro may have some leftover prejudices, but he's nevertheless a hero and one who can inspire if one can get passed racial divide.

The best thing about Men Of Honor is the chemistry between DeNiro and Gooding. They certainly come from different places, but as they get to know each other, both turn out to be Men Of Honor.

Other good performances to note are Charlize Theron as DeNiro's wife and Hal Holbrook as the head of the diving school, a guy the Navy just wish would retire for reasons you'll see.

Men Of Honor is an inspiring story about people with courage to spare and the ability to change.If you think this sentence is positive, the answer is 1, and the negative answer is 0 Use following thought to solve it:###Thinking Let's tackle this question by analyzing the text to determine if the sentence "Men Of Honor is an inspiring story about people with courage to spare and the ability to change" is positive or negative. The review highlights the challenges Brashear faced, with the Navy initially restricting him to roles like cook or valet. However, Gooding's character doesn't settle for that and applies to become a Navy deep sea diver, showing determination and courage. At diving school, Gooding faces tough treatment from Robert DeNiro's character, the Master Chief Petty Officer. While DeNiro's character may have initial prejudices, the review notes that he's a hero who can inspire if one can get past the racial divide. The chemistry between DeNiro and Gooding is highlighted as the best thing about the movie, emphasizing their transformation from adversaries to Men Of Honor. Other performances are also commended, with Charlize Theron as DeNiro's wife and Hal Holbrook as the head of the diving school receiving praise. The review mentions that the Navy wishes Holbrook's character would retire, but doesn't provide a negative connotation, focusing instead on the story's inspiring nature. Throughout the review, words like "inspiration," "courage," "hero," "chemistry," and "ability to change" are used, all of which have positive connotations. There's a sense of admiration for the characters and the actors playing them. Even when discussing the challenges and prejudices, the focus is on how the characters overcome these obstacles, which is portrayed in a positive light. Wait, could there be any negative aspects hidden in the text? The review mentions the Navy's restrictions and the tough treatment at diving school, but these are presented as challenges to be overcome rather than criticisms of the movie. The reviewer seems to be highlighting the contrast between the old guard and the new era of change. The concluding sentence directly states, "Men Of Honor is an inspiring story about people with courage to spare and the ability to change." It would really benefit from a few early clues as to who these people are and what they are doing. Probably better for the US market. GC himself hinted that this alone did not supply his Oscar and you can see why.

Still the sand dunes are pretty. The nail pulling is nasty. The attorneys drunk dad is a mystery. The cricket is good to see.

Very difficult to write the required ten lines on this, despite it being over 2 hours long. Thank heavens they shortened it. Admittedly we don't get to the pictures much, but the last film we saw, Walk the Line, was 10 times better and I don't really like Johnny Cash. results.question:
Given the question statement:"Who Done It?" contains many surefire laughs and gags. It is not only one of the best Stooges films with Shemp, it is one of the finest short comedies Columbia produced. Director Bernds originally wrote the screenplay in 1946 for the Stooges, but when Curly Howard suffered a career-ending stroke, it was tailored for the Columbia comedy team of Schilling and Lane (their version was released as "Pardon My Terror.") It obviously was too good for the Stooges to pass up, and it was finally filmed by the Stooges at the end of 1947.

Old Man Goodrich calls ace detectives Shemp, Larry, and Moe out of fear that he will be murdered. When they arrive at his home, Goodrich has disappeared, and his niece and assorted goons try to get rid of the Stooges. Will they find Goodrich and bring the niece and goons to justice?

Shemp is particularly funny in this film. His reactions after being given a mickey by Christine McIntyre are superb; he gives his trademark sound (eeeb-eeeb-eeeb) and Miss McIntyre is noticeably trying not to laugh! Other funny scenes: the close-up of Moe's mug looking through the camera lens; and the in-the-dark fight with all cast members involved.

Nikko the goon (played by Duke York) is one of the most unusual looking characters ever portrayed in a Stooges film. With his kinked hair, he could almost pass for a Stooge, if he didn't tower over everyone else! "Who Done It?" is a gem among the Stooges films with Shemp. Even die-hard Curly fans will enjoy this one! A true Stooge classic. 9 out of 10.If you think this sentence is positive, the answer is 1, and the negative answer is 0 Use following thought to solve it:###Thinking Let's tackle this review of the Three Stooges short "Who Done It?" These specific examples demonstrate that the reviewer found the film consistently amusing. Wait, the reviewer also mentions Nikko the goon, played by Duke York, describing him as "one of the most unusual looking characters ever portrayed in a Stooges film." This adds to the film's appeal, suggesting it has memorable characters that enhance the comedy. Even the title of the review, "Who Done It?" is likely a play on the film's title, adding a touch of humor and engagement. The reviewer reassures Curly fans that they will enjoy this film as well, broadening the appeal and emphasizing that it's a classic Stooge comedy. The review concludes with a strong statement: "A true Stooge classic. 9 out of 10." This rating leaves no doubt about the reviewer's positive opinion. A 9 out of 10 is a high score, indicating that the reviewer thought the film was exceptional. I did consider whether there might be any negative aspects, but the review is overwhelmingly positive. The only potential hint of a negative could be the mention of the screenplay being adapted for Schilling and Lane, but the reviewer frames this as the script being "too good for the Stooges to pass up," which is actually a compliment to the Stooges and the script. While the review is positive, it's not hyperbolic to the point of being insincere. The reviewer provides specific examples and historical context, which adds credibility to their opinion. The mention of die-hard Curly fans enjoying the film shows that the reviewer has thought about the film's appeal to different audiences. Given the question statement:I actually have a fondness for Christopher Lee, but this just wasn't up to his other performances... and he was one of the better actors.

The film does not live up to its premise. It's not that scary, it's overly melodramatic, and it draaaaaags. Every time I thought, "Oh, HERE comes the good part" the good part never quite arrived.

The Evil Ones aren't at all convincing. Most of the other characters were also lacking in depth.

Perhaps if I'd been in the proper frame of mind, I might have enjoyed some MSTie-fication at this film's expense, but.... Naaahhh... Didn't really seem to be worth the effort. It wasn't really very good, it wasn't really very bad, it was just mediocre.If you think this sentence is positive, the answer is 1, and the negative answer is 0 Use following thought to solve it:###Thinking Let's tackle this movie review and determine whether it's positive or negative. The reviewer starts by mentioning a fondness for Christopher Lee, which is a nice touch, but then immediately qualifies that sentiment by stating, "this just wasn't up to his other performances... and he was one of the better actors." Wait, so even though the reviewer likes Lee, they're saying he wasn't great in this film. That's already a bit of a downer. Moving on, the review says the film "does not live up to its premise." That's a clear criticism right there. The reviewer elaborates by stating it's "not that scary," which is a significant failing for a horror movie, assuming that's the genre. They also describe it as "overly melodramatic," which suggests the acting or writing went over the top in a way that was off-putting. Then there's the complaint about the pacing: "it draaaaaags." The drawn-out "draaaaaags" really emphasizes how slow the movie felt. Every time the reviewer thought, "Oh, HERE comes the good part," the good part never arrived. That's frustrating and indicates a lack of engaging moments. The "Evil Ones" aren't convincing, and "most of the other characters were also lacking in depth." So, the characters aren't working either. The reviewer even considers the possibility of enjoying the film through MST3K-style mockery—watching it with friends and making fun of it—but dismisses that idea. They think, "Naaahhh... Didn't really seem to be worth the effort." That's a pretty strong indication of their dislike. They sum up the film as "mediocre." Now, is "mediocre" positive or negative? The word itself means average or ordinary, neither good nor bad. However, in the context of this review, "mediocre" is clearly used as a criticism. The reviewer has spent the entire time pointing out the film's shortcomings, so when they say it's just mediocre, they're emphasizing that it's not worth watching. I did consider the mention of Christopher Lee and the reviewer's fondness for him, thinking maybe there's some positivity lurking. But the overall tone is overwhelmingly negative. The reviewer is disappointed, frustrated, and unimpressed. They even say, "It wasn't really very good, it wasn't really very bad, it was just mediocre." This feels like a backhanded compliment at best. I also thought about the phrase "if I'd been in the proper frame of mind, I might have enjoyed some MSTie-fication at this film's expense." Maybe they're hinting at a positive aspect? But no, they follow it with "but.... Naaahhh... Didn't really seem to be worth the effort." So, even the potential for enjoying it in a mocking way isn't enough to tip the scales. Perhaps the reviewer is being diplomatic, not wanting to be too harsh on Christopher Lee? But the rest of the review is pretty scathing. They could have focused on Lee's performance if they wanted to be positive, but instead, they highlight his lackluster contribution. At one point, I wondered if "not that scary" might be a good thing for some viewers, but the context makes it clear the reviewer expected more scares and was disappointed. The mention of the film being "overly melodramatic" and dragging further reinforces the negative tone. I also considered the possibility that the reviewer might have some underlying positive feelings, but the consistent negativity throughout the review makes that unlikely. They're not highlighting any redeeming qualities or expressing any enthusiasm for the film. results.question:
Given the question statement:After watching many of the "Next Action Star" reality TV eps TiVo taped this gawd-awful tripe for me. For some bizarre reason - and I only have myself to blame - I watched the whole thing, hoping that there would be *something* unique in the entire movie. After so much hype about Joel Silver's "Midas Touch" with action flicks, he might want to make sure he bones up on his alchemy.

First, the only redeeming value of the entire film was Billy Zane, and even he couldn't lift the slipshod writing out of the crapper. Having said that, Zane's performance falters about 2/ 3rds of the way through, as he doesn't even seem to know what else to do other than look smug.

Can't blame him here, though. The writing, quite frankly, sucked. Let's take ideas from "Rat Race," "Enemy of the State," "Terminator," "Midnight Run" and any bad gambling film you can think of and simply rehash it. And who's brilliant idea was it to have TWO bridge chase sequences in a ROW?

Sean Carrigan, the "man of the hour" of "The Next Action Star" shows all of the strengths and weaknesses the casting directors mention during the entire run of the series. A one-note johnny, Sean plays the dumb good looking jock very well, but struggles with shouldering the weight of the film. Quite frankly, we never quite seem to care about whether he lives or dies by about mid-way through, as Carrigan fails to provide a reason for the audience to even like him. His dumb-but-lucky routine gets old as there really isn't anything about the character to root for.

But Carrigan is a dream compared to the wooden, rigid Corinne Van Ryck de Groot. Did Howard Fine really tell her to pretend to be a Terminator for the first half of the film? I don't think so. I kept expecting her to quote Arnie. Her character "performance" can be compared only to the dramatic depths of "Freddy Got Fingered," though not nearly as well-developed. The camera loves her in dark, shadowy limousines, but in the harsh light of day her demeanor sucks all energy off the screen. Jeanne Bauer showed more natural life in her five minute bit part than Corinne showed at any part of her screen time.

Ultimately, Sean has the rugged good looks to provide a good lead in an ensemble cast, but shouldn't have been left to do this one solo. It was simply too big of a task for him. "Next Action Star" colleague Jared Elliot may or may not have had better luck with some more dynamic characterization, but it's hard to tell given Jeff Welch's lame script. Someone should take Welch's iMac away from him before he hurts himself or anyone else. And finally, Van Ryck de Groot simply was outclassed and way out of her reach, even for complete shlock like this.

Joel Silver should be ashamed.If you think this sentence is positive, the answer is 1, and the negative answer is 0 Use following thought to solve it:###Thinking Let's tackle this problem by analyzing the given text to determine whether the sentence "Joel Silver should be ashamed" is positive or negative. The text is a scathing movie review, and the language used is overwhelmingly negative. The reviewer expresses disappointment with various aspects of the film, particularly criticizing the writing, acting, and direction. First, the reviewer mentions that the only redeeming value of the film was Billy Zane, but even his performance falters towards the end. This suggests that Zane's performance isn't enough to save the movie. The writing is described as "slipshod" and "sucked," with the reviewer criticizing the film for rehashing ideas from other movies like "Rat Race," "Enemy of the State," "Terminator," "Midnight Run," and bad gambling films. The inclusion of two bridge chase sequences in a row is mocked, indicating the reviewer found the plot predictable and clichéd. The lead actor, Sean Carrigan, is praised for his good looks and ability to play a dumb jock but is criticized for struggling to shoulder the weight of the film. The reviewer states that we stop caring about his character midway through, and his "dumb-but-lucky" routine gets old. Carrigan is described as a "one-note johnny," suggesting his performance lacks depth. Corinne Van Ryck de Groot is lambasted for her wooden and rigid performance, with the reviewer comparing her to the Terminator and stating that her demeanor sucks all energy off the screen. Jeanne Bauer's brief appearance is mentioned as showing more natural life than Van Ryck de Groot's entire screen time. The reviewer concludes that Sean Carrigan has the rugged good looks to be a good lead in an ensemble cast but shouldn't have been left to carry the film alone. They suggest that Jared Elliot might have had better luck with a more dynamic characterization, but it's hard to tell given the lame script. The scriptwriter, Jeff Welch, is criticized harshly, with the reviewer stating that someone should take his iMac away before he hurts himself or anyone else. Finally, the reviewer directly addresses Joel Silver, the producer, stating that he should be ashamed. Throughout the review, the tone is consistently negative, with the reviewer expressing disappointment and frustration with the film. Given the question statement:Some of the posters seem less than gruntled because this is neither Mark Twain nor Rodgers and Hart but clearly it doesn't pretend to be either. You'll look a long time to find a greater Rodgers and Hart fan than me but Burke and Van Heusen weren't exactly chopped liver in addition to which they knew Der Bingle inside out and tailored some great songs - But Beautiful, Moonlight Becomes You, It's Always You, The Day After Forever, etc - to fit his highly personal style and here they come up with yet another fine - and unfairly neglected - ballad, Once And For Always, plus a couple of upbeat philosophy-lite entries in If You Stub Your Toe On The Moon and Busy Doing Nothing. The flimsy plot isn't meant to be taken seriously - why else make Merlin a heavy when in most, if not all, of the other versions he is more a friend/mentor to Arthur - so if you start wondering aloud why Sir Lancelot who has been sold to historians as the epitome of chivalry and uprightness metamorphoses into a schoolyard bully you're not going to get much fun out of what is essentially a fun movie. On balance it does what it sets out to do, entertain, so good luck to it.If you think this sentence is positive, the answer is 1, and the negative answer is 0 Use following thought to solve it:###Thinking Let's tackle this movie review and determine whether the overall sentiment is positive or negative. They knew Frank Sinatra ("Der Bingle") inside out and tailored some great songs to fit his style, mentioning hits like "But Beautiful," "Moonlight Becomes You," "It's Always You," and "The Day After Forever." This is definitely positive. The reviewer then mentions that Burke and Van Heusen come up with yet another fine—and unfairly neglected—ballad, "Once And For Always," plus a couple of upbeat philosophy-lite entries in "If You Stub Your Toe On The Moon" and "Busy Doing Nothing." More positive praise for the music! However, the plot is described as flimsy and not meant to be taken seriously. results.question:
Given the question statement:Whether you watch the regular version of this monstrosity or the MST3K version, you can only be impressed by the utter GALL that went into this production. The filmmakers insult the viewer's intelligence from one end to the other and obviously couldn't care less that they are doing so.

Everything about it is rock-bottom cheap. Even the 1950s car in the flashback sequence to that era looks like it was hauled out of a junkyard.

The "hobgoblins" are, as you probably know, "realized" with badly-crafted hand puppets and stuffed toys; when a person is supposed to be attacked by them, it's clear the toy is being held by the victim to his or her own body. When the critters scurry away from the two security guards, this is shown (or rather, not shown) by the camera aiming UP at the guards as they look down and turn their heads as if watching the hobgoblins scurrying past. It's reminiscent of the scene in the film "Tangents" where two people are standing in the ruins of a future world, surveying the wreckage, and we aren't shown any of it. Budget constraints alloyed with utter incompetence generally mean you won't have anything worth showing, so why try? The "sets" were utterly laughable. "Club Scum" was an obvious diner; the house appears to have been a vacant house --probably for rent or sale-- which the production company got hold of for an hour or two to do the shoot. The "spacecraft" is something I would have been ashamed to build when I was a model-making 10 year-old.

The motivations of the characters make no sense-- Kevin gets denigrated by his worthless ingrate of a girlfriend because he hasn't made her "proud of him." I'm sure this was intended to make their reconciliation oh so touching at the end, but any guy with real self-respect would have told her to go to hell and left her. Nick is supposedly back from 2 months of Army training (yeah, nice regulation haircut, Nick,) and seems bent on proving that our country is being defended by sadistic, moronic animals who are sex maniacs. Kyle is a phone-sex freak in red shorts who dreams of a night with a spandex-clad dominatrix type, but he's so effeminate that he's more likely gay than not. One of the girls is a prude and the other is a sleaze.

And the hobgoblins? At the end they all head back to the vault where they've lived for 30 years. Why? Who knows? Who cares? Watch this film and be amazed at how primitive film-making in our modern age can be when you have an idiotic script, incompetent direction, actors who are so bad they'd be rejected from a high school theater production, and sets worthy of Edward D. Wood, Jr.If you think this sentence is positive, the answer is 1, and the negative answer is 0 Use following thought to solve it:###Thinking Let's tackle this review and determine whether it's positive or negative.
